title: Bowen v. Bowen
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Ann B. Bowen, Respondent,
v.
Richard W. Bowen, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Â Thomas Kemmerlin, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-303
Heard March 9, 2005 â€“ Filed May 5, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Donald B. Clark, and, Morris D. Rosen, both of Charleston, for Appellant.
Peter L. Fuge, of Beaufort, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Richard W. Bowen (Husband) appeals the circuit courtâ€™s inclusion of post-judgment interest in its determination of the amount Husband owed to Ann B. Bowen (Wife) for the sale of four jointly-titled properties.Â  The circuit court enforced its previous order, awarding Wife a one-half interest in the proceeds from the sale plus post-judgment interest.Â  We affirm. 
FACTS
The parties married in 1985.Â  Prior to the marriage, the parties entered into an antenuptial agreement.Â  The agreement provided that all property owned prior to or accumulated during the marriage would remain each partyâ€™s separate, non-marital property.Â  During the marriage, Husband acquired four parcels of property and titled each parcel in the names of Husband and Wife.Â  In 1992, Wife commenced a divorce action against Husband and sought equitable distribution of the four jointly titled parcels.Â  The family court, pursuant to the antenuptial agreement, found the properties were non-marital in nature, but awarded each an undivided one-half interest in the properties.Â  
On appeal, this court vacated the portion of the family courtâ€™s order addressing the partiesâ€™ interests in the four parcels of property, holding the family court lacks jurisdiction to determine ownership of non-marital property.Â  Bowen v. Bowen, 327 S.C. 561, 566, 490 S.E.2d 271, 273 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  Thereafter, Wife filed a declaratory judgment action.Â  By order dated March 19, 1999, the circuit court found Husband gifted Wife an undivided one-half interest in the four parcels of property.Â  Because the properties were sold during the pendency of the appeal and all funds were held in escrow, the circuit court awarded Wife one-half of the proceeds from the sale.Â  Accordingly, the circuit court ruled that â€œ[Wife] is entitled to immediate payment of the same [proceeds] plus interest at the legal rate accruing from the date of each deedâ€ and ordered that â€œEach party owing money to the other shall pay to such other 8 3/4 % interest on such money from the time the other was entitled to it until it is paid.â€Â  
Husband appealed arguing he did not intend to make a gift of the properties to Wife and the usual presumption of a gift from a husband to a wife did not apply when the parties had entered into a valid antenuptial agreement.Â  Thus, he argued the circuit court should have imposed a resulting trust on the proceeds from the sale.Â  Bowen v. Bowen, 345 S.C. 243, 249, 547 S.E.2d 877, 880 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  We disagreed and affirmed the circuit courtâ€™s order.Â  Id. at 251, 547 S.E.2d at 881.Â  Subsequently, Husband appealed to the supreme court which held: â€œthe Court of Appeals properly affirmed the Masterâ€™s findings that Wife owned an undivided one-half interest in the four properties.â€Â  Bowen v. Bowen, 352 S.C. 494, 556, 575 S.E.2d 553, 556 (2003).Â  The supreme court then sent the remittitur to the circuit court.Â  
Thereafter, Wife filed a rule to show cause for contempt and requested that the court calculate all sums due her plus interest and order Husband to pay such sums immediately.Â  The circuit court calculated the total Husband owed to Wife, including interest, and ordered Husband to pay.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Husband argues the circuit court erred by including post-judgment interest in its calculation of the total amount Husband owed to Wife.Â  We disagree.
â€œA portion of a judgment that is not appealed presents no issue for determination by the reviewing court and constitutes, rightly or wrongly, the law of the case.â€Â  Austin v. Specialty Transp. Servs., 358 S.C. 298, 320, 594 S.E.2d 867, 878 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  It is a fundamental rule of law that an appellate court will affirm a ruling by a trial court if the offended party does not challenge that ruling.Â  Biales v. Young, 315 S.C. 166, 168, 432 S.E.2d 482, 484 (1993).Â  Failure to challenge the ruling â€œis an abandonment of the issue and precludes consideration on appeal.â€Â  Id. at 168, 432 S.E.2d at 484. 
Pursuant to the order dated March 19, 1999, in calculating the total sum Husband owed to Wife from the sale of the four properties, the circuit court included interest at the rate of 8 3/4 %.Â  Husband contends Wife had no right to interest because funds held in escrow do not constitute a money judgment that accrues interest pursuant to Section 34-31-20 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2004).Â  However, Husband did not raise this issue when he appealed the circuit courtâ€™s March 19, 1999 judgment.Â  Our supreme court affirmed the circuit courtâ€™s order including the award of interest in Bowen v. Bowen, 352 S.C. 494, 556, 575 S.E.2d 553, 556 (2003) and sent a remittitur to the circuit court.Â  Therefore, the circuit courtâ€™s award of interest stands as the law of the case and presents no issue for determination on appeal.Â  Accordingly, the circuit courtâ€™s order is 
AFFIRMED.Â  
HEARN, C.J., KITTREDGE and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

title: Ashy v. ACHI Investments
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDINGÂ Â  EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Tony J. Ashy, Appellant,
v.
ACHI Investments, LLC and Ramon J. Ashy, Jr., Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Anderson County
Â Ellis B. Drew, Jr., Master-in-Equity

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-304
Submitted April 1, 2005 â€“ Filed May 5, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Bernie W. Ellis, of Greenville, Robert L. Widener, of Columbia and Robert P. Lusk, of Anderson, for Appellant.
David Lloyd Thomas, of Greenville and Michael F. Mullinax, of Anderson, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Tony J. Ashy appeals a master-in-equityâ€™s decision upholding the validity of a deed from Tony to ACHI Investments, LLC.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
This appeal concerns the validity of a general warranty deed dated August 23, 2000, whereby Tony conveyed a 2.661-acre parcel of land to ACHI Investments for the stated sum of $75,000.00.Â  The deed was recorded in the Office of the Clerk of Court for Anderson County on August 31, 2000.Â  ACHI is a limited liability company owned by Tonyâ€™s nephew, Ramon J. Ashy, Jr., and his brother (Ramonâ€™s father).Â Â Â Â Â  
In early 2000, Tony discussed selling his 2.661-acre parcel in Anderson County with Ramon.Â  At that time, according to Ramon, Tony wanted $50,000.00 for the property.Â Â Â  
Additional negotiations occurred on August 22, 2000, when Tony, Ramon, and Ramonâ€™s father met for lunch in Greenville.Â  Tony told Ramon he would take no less than $75,000.00 for the property â€œbecause thatâ€™s what [he] owe[d] on it.â€Â  Tony testified he then phoned his wife, who told him he â€œha[d] too much money tied up in that propertyâ€ to sell it. Â After the partiesâ€™ finished their lunch, Ramon let Tony borrow his car because Tonyâ€™s vehicle was being repaired.Â Â Â  
The next afternoon, according to Tony, Ramon called and asked him to bring the car to his office.Â  Once at the office, Ramon asked Tony to sign a payoff request from the bank â€œbecause the bank would not tell [him] how much [Tony] owe[d] on that property without [his] signature.â€Â  Tony willingly signed the document, and Ramon faxed it to the bank.Â  Instead of driving Tony back to his motherâ€™s house, as Tony expected him to, Ramon stopped at the Pfeiffer and Gantt law firm in Greenville, where Tony signed several other documents.Â Â Â  
In contrast, Ramon testified Tony knew they were going to the law firm and had scheduled an appointment for that day with the hopes of completing the closing while Tony was still in Greenville.Â  The law firm had already ordered appraisals and title searches the day before when Tony and Ramon had discussed the sales price of the property.Â  While at the law firm, Tony signed several documents:Â  a Form 1099-S recognition, a sellerâ€™s indemnity affidavit, and a general warranty deed.Â  David Gantt, a closing attorney and a partner in the law firm of Pfeiffer and Gantt, and Tilda Burgess, a paralegal, witnessed the deed.Â  There never was a separate, written contract for the sale or escrow of the property.Â Â Â Â  
Over the objection of Tonyâ€™s attorney, Gantt recorded the deed on August 31, 2000.Â  Gantt tendered a check to BB&T to pay off the mortgage and also sent a check of the net proceeds to Tonyâ€™s attorney.Â  According to Gantt, Tony was not paid for the property at the time of closing on August 23rd as the closing had originally been scheduled for the following week on August 30th, so he held the deed in escrow pending the arrival of funds from Palmetto Bank the following week.Â  
The master upheld the validity of the deed, finding Tony was aware of the contents of the deed and he â€œfully intended to deliver the deed to Gantt to be held pending only the receipt of the proceeds.â€Â  The master concluded there was no legal requirement for a written contract in this case, stating:Â  â€œPart performance, in actuality, complete performance[,] took place when Tony Ashy signed all documents at the closing on August 23, 2000 including the general warranty deed and delivered this deed to Gantt to hold in escrow until the sales proceeds were received.Â  There is no statute of frauds argument in the context of the evidence in this case.â€Â Â Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
On appeal, Tony claims the master erred in upholding the validity of the deed because there was no contract of sale or escrow contract supported by valid consideration, thereby violating the Statute of Frauds.Â  We disagree.
â€œA deed is not legally effective until it has been delivered.â€Â  Donnan v. Mariner, 339 S.C. 621, 627, 529 S.E.2d 754, 757 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  Although there is no prescribed method for an effective delivery, the controlling question is the intent of the grantor at the time of the transaction.Â  Id.Â  If a grantor delivers a deed to a grantee or in escrow â€œintending to part with control overâ€ it, the fee passes immediately to the grantees named within the deed.Â  Watson v. Cox, 117 S.C. 24, 28-29, 108 S.E. 168, 169 (1921).Â  
â€œAn escrow is a deed delivered to a third person upon a future condition to be performed by either party.â€Â  Brockington v. Lynch, 119 S.C. 273, 299, 112 S.E. 94, 103 (1922).Â  Every element of a valid escrow appears where â€œ[t]here are sufficient parties, a proper subject-matter, a consideration, and the parties have . . . contractedâ€ to place a deed in the hands of a third party to be delivered under the condition stated.Â  Id. at 299-300, 112 S.E. at 103.Â  Furthermore, an escrow cannot be revoked unless provided for in the agreement accompanying the escrow.Â  Id. at 300, 112 S.E. at 103.Â  Finally, an agreement to convey real property must be in writing â€œand signed by the party to be charged,â€ as required by the Statute of Frauds.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 32-3-10(4) (1991).Â  
Tony testified he did not know he was signing a deed to convey his property and he never intended to sell the property.Â  Tony claimed Gantt asked him to be a witness in a lawsuit against Michael Alakhwan, who allegedly owed Tony money.Â  Tony thought the documents related to that case and Gantt needed him to testify on August 30 or 31, 2000.Â  
In contrast, Gantt recalled going over each of the documents with Tony.Â  Gantt told Tony he was signing a general warranty deed in consideration of $75,000 being delivered on August 30, 2000.Â  Gantt merely held the deed in escrow pending receipt of the funds.Â  The delay occurred because the closing had originally been scheduled for the following week.Â  Gantt maintained Tony agreed to these terms.Â  The closing lasted between thirty-five and forty minutes.Â Â Â  
Tina Burgess, a former paralegal at the law firm who helped with the closing, testified Tony â€œdid not seem to have a problemâ€ understanding or reading any of the documents placed in front of him.Â  Burgess and Gantt witnessed Tonyâ€™s signature on the deed.Â Â Â   
Burgess recalled Tonyâ€™s wife, Debbie Ashy, contacted the law firm on August 29, 2000, and asked when the proceeds from the sale would be distributed.Â  That day, Burgess faxed Debbie the documents signed at the closing with an attached note indicating the distribution of proceeds would be on August 31, 2000.Â  In contradiction to Tonyâ€™s statement about his wifeâ€™s concern of having too much money tied up in the property, Debbie testified she would have minded â€œ[n]ot a bitâ€ if Tony had sold the property.Â  She asserted, however, he did not realize what he had signed.Â  
â€œWe have consistently followed the rule that ordinarily one cannot complain of fraud in the misrepresentation of the contents of a written instrument signed by him when the truth could have been ascertained by reading the instrument, and that one entering into a written contract should read it and avail himself of every reasonable opportunity to understand its content and meaning.â€Â  Oâ€™Connor v. Bhd. of R.R. Trainmen, 217 S.C. 442, 449, 60 S.E.2d 884, 886 (1950).
â€œThe rule is subject to the exception, which is very strictly interpreted by our Supreme Court, that if the party is ignorant and unwary, his failure to read the document may be excused.â€Â  Stanley Smith & Sons v. D.M.R., Inc., 307 S.C. 413, 417, 415 S.E.2d 428, 431 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  â€œThe court must consider an individualâ€™s education, business experience and intelligence in deciding whether a party may be classified as ignorant and unwary.â€Â  Id.  
The record is replete with evidence of Tonyâ€™s abilities and business experience, including his ownership and operation of a nightclub, a bingo hall, and a gun and police supply store.Â  At the time of this suit, he owned five automobiles, including four Mercedes and â€œone (1) old Rolls-Royce.â€Â  He and his wife owned several properties with a net worth of close to a million dollars.Â  In fact, he acknowledged during cross-examination that he was not altogether an unsophisticated businessman, stating, â€œSometimes. Â Depends.â€Â Â Â  
As evidenced by Tonyâ€™s signature on multiple documents, including the pay-off request signed before he even attended the closing, the testimony of Gantt and Burgess, inconsistencies in some of Tonyâ€™s rendition of events, and Tonyâ€™s business experience, we can find no error in the masterâ€™s conclusion that Tony intended to deed the property to ACHI on August 23, 2000, contingent only upon receiving the loan proceeds the following week.Â  As noted by the master, the deed itself served to document the transaction, and it was signed by the party to be charged.Â  Accordingly, we agree with the master that the deed was an effective conveyance of the property. 
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, HUFF, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: State v. Boseman
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDINGÂ Â  EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Vincent Boseman, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â J. Mark Hayes, II, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-305
Heard April 4, 2005 â€“ Filed May 5, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Tara S. Taggart, South Carolina Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott,Â  Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Warren Blair Giese, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Following a retrial, Vincent Boseman was convicted of armed robbery, simple assault, and resisting arrest.Â  He appeals, arguing the trial court committed reversible error by incorporating certain pretrial rulings from his first trial into the current proceeding.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
At the first trial in December 2000, Boseman was convicted of armed robbery, assault of a high and aggravated nature (AHAN), and resisting arrest for a robbery that occurred on February 14, 1997, at the Town and Tourist motel in Columbia, South Carolina.Â  He was sentenced to life in prison without parole.Â  On appeal, this Court reversed and remanded the matter for a new trial based on an error in remedying a Batson[1] challenge.Â  See State v. Boseman, Op. No. 2003-UP-096 (S.C. Ct. App. filed Feb. 4, 2003).
At the retrial in July 2003, the State filed a document entitled â€œNo Subsequent Motion,â€ which sought, pursuant to Rule 4(b), SCRCrimP, to prevent any further motions about identification, search and seizure, and other issues of law decided in the first trial that had not been appealed or reversed by an appellate court.[2]Â  On the first day of trial, the State noted it would have one new witness who would have to be examined in camera, but sought to â€œbe allowed to go straight forward in front of the juryâ€ with any witness who had already testified in camera as to the show-up and in-court identifications during the first trial on the basis the judge in the first trial had already found their testimony to be admissible.Â  Defense counsel objected, arguing the current trial was a new proceeding for which the previous rulings were not binding.Â  
The trial court stated it would â€œaccept Judge Williamsâ€™s [James C. Williams, Jr.] rulings that were made as being bound upon this court as far as what those witnesses would testify to, and also the decisions and conclusions reached by Judge Williams in the prior proceeding.â€Â  The court ordered that portions of the trial transcript, including the pretrial motions and the rulings on those motions, be incorporated into the record of the current proceeding.[3]Â  
At the conclusion of the trial, Boseman was convicted of armed robbery, simple assault (as a lesser-included offense of AHAN), and resisting arrest.Â  He was again sentenced to life in prison without parole.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In criminal cases, an appellate court sits to review errors of law only.Â  State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 545 S.E.2d 827 (2001).Â  The appellate court is bound by the trial courtâ€™s preliminary factual findings in determining the admissibility of certain evidence in criminal cases, and on appeal we are limited to determining whether the trial court abused its discretion.Â  Id.Â  We do not re-evaluate the facts based on our own view of the preponderance of the evidence, but instead simply determine whether the trial courtâ€™s ruling is supported by any evidence.Â  Id.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
On appeal, Boseman argues the trial court committed reversible error warranting a new trial by incorporating as binding certain portions of the pretrial transcript and rulings from his first trial.Â  We disagree.
At the first trial in 2000, Willie McCalvin and Carl Holmes identified Boseman as the person who had robbed a group of people at gunpoint at the Town and Tourist motel on February 14, 1997.Â  
At the second trial in 2003, Carl Holmes did not testify.Â  Willie McCalvin was the first witness up and testified in detail about the events of the robbery.Â  McCalvin made an in-court identification of Boseman as the robber without objection.Â  
A new witness who did not testify at the first trial, Howard Smith, was introduced at the retrial and subjected to an in camera review by the trial court.Â  Smith confirmed that he had immediately identified Boseman to the police at the scene when the incident occurred in 1997, but he was not able to make an in-court identification of Boseman at the time of this trial in 2003.Â  
Thus, the issue of incorporating the first trialâ€™s pretrial rulings is relevant only as to McCalvin, who testified in camera during the first trialâ€™s pretrial hearing and who testified at the retrial.Â  
Initially, we question whether the issue raised here is preserved.Â  The trial courtâ€™s ruling regarding the admissibility of the evidence was made after the jury was selected but before it was sworn, which normally would be considered an in limine ruling.Â  Where a ruling on the admissibility of evidence is made in limine, it is generally not a final ruling and is subject to change pending developments at trial.Â  State v. Forrester, 343 S.C. 637, 541 S.E.2d 837 (2001).Â  Thus, any objection must be renewed when the evidence comes in.Â  Id.Â  As noted above, however, no objection was made to McCalvinâ€™s identification of Boseman.[4]Â  
This case is unusual, however, because the trial court indicated it was making a final ruling in this regard by stating it was â€œboundâ€ by the decision in the first trial.Â  Further, McCalvin was the first witness up and no evidence came in between the courtâ€™s ruling and the identification; however, before McCalvin testified, the court heard Smithâ€™s in camera testimony, made rulings on other pretrial matters, instructed the jury on general procedures and had them sworn, following which counsel for both sides made opening statements.Â  Cf. State v. Mueller, 319 S.C. 266, 268-69, 460 S.E.2d 409, 410-11 (Ct. App. 1995) (stating an in limine motion is a pretrial procedure and the ruling is subject to change depending on the development of the case, so the losing party must renew his objection at trial to preserve the issue for appeal; the court held that a ruling on the admissibility of evidence made immediately before a witness testified during trial was not a preliminary ruling, but was final, thus distinguishing it from an in limine motion, and that the party was not required to renew an objection). 
Even if the issue raised here is preserved, we nevertheless find no error warranting reversal.Â  
When evidence is erroneously admitted, â€œreversal is not required unless the appellant was prejudiced by the error.â€Â  State v. Mitchell, 286 S.C. 572, 573, 336 S.E.2d 150, 151 (1985) (citation omitted).Â  

Whether an error is harmless depends on the circumstances of the particular case.Â  No definite rule of law governs this finding; rather, the materiality and prejudicial character of the error must be determined from its relationship to the entire case.Â  Error is harmless when it â€œcould not reasonably have affected the result of the trial.â€

Id. (quoting State v. Key, 256 S.C. 90, 180 S.E.2d 888 (1971)).
We hold that, even assuming the trial court committed error, Boseman has not shown what, if any, prejudice he has suffered that would justify a reversal.
In addition to McCalvinâ€™s testimony identifying Boseman, another victim, Howard Smith, testified about the robbery as noted above and confirmed that immediately after the incident, he had identified Boseman to police at the scene.Â  The police had immediately descended on the motel and apprehended Boseman after hearing a shot Boseman fired as he left the victimsâ€™ room.Â  Additionally, officer Brian Oâ€™Connell testified that a search at the scene revealed Boseman had in his possession a cell phone, identification, and money belonging to the victims.Â  This evidence came in without objection.Â  Based on the foregoing, we find any testimony offered by McCalvin could not have prejudiced this case and note that Boseman has offered no specific arguments or evidence regarding any prejudice.Â  
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, HUFF, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  Batson v. Kentucky, 476 U.S. 79 (1986).
[2]Â  Rule 4(b) provides:Â  â€œIf any motion be made to any judge and be denied, in whole or in part, or be granted conditionally, no subsequent motion upon the same set of facts shall be made to any other judge in that action.Â  If upon such subsequent motion any order be made, it shall be void.â€Â  Rule 4(b), SCRCrimP.Â  The State also asserts in the motion that â€œthe parties are collaterally estopped from re-arguing the same issues,â€ but the concept of collateral estoppel clearly is not implicated here.Â  
[3]Â  In its brief, the State argues the incorporation of the pretrial rulings was â€œpreciselyâ€ what Boseman wanted.Â  This statement is misleading, however.Â  Once the trial court determined the previous pretrial rulings would be binding, Boseman then agreed, despite his continuing objection to the ruling, that he wanted the transcript incorporated into the record for purposes of appeal.Â  
[4]Â  Further, items recovered from Boseman by the police also came in without objection.Â  At the end of the trial, defense counsel did move for a mistrial.Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Larry Wayne Pressley and Linda Pressley,       
Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Jason Keith Blackwell,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Cherokee County
Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-306
Heard April 4, 2005 â€“ Filed May 6, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Charles T. Deal, of Clemson, for Appellants. 
Edward R. Cole, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

STILWELL, J.:Â  Larry Wayne and Linda Pressley appeal the trial courtâ€™s order granting summary judgment to Jason Keith Blackwell on the ground that the Pressleysâ€™ claim was barred by the statute of limitations.Â  Counsel for the Pressleys also argues he received insufficient notice of the summary judgment hearing.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Larry Wayne Pressley and Blackwell were involved in a motor vehicle accident in Cherokee County on June 5, 1999.Â  Blackwellâ€™s liability insurer paid its entire coverage to the Pressleys in exchange for a covenant not to execute.Â  On May 31, 2002, the Pressleys filed this action in Anderson County in an attempt to collect from their underinsured motorist carrier, Nationwide Insurance Company (Nationwide).Â  
On June 3, 2002, the Pressleys attempted to serve the summons and complaint on Blackwell through the Cherokee County Sheriffâ€™s Office.Â  The next day, the Sheriffâ€™s Office reported Blackwell could not be served, noting the reason as â€œEmpty resident/No forwarding address.â€Â  
On June 20, 2002, the Pressleys served Nationwide through the Department of Insurance.Â  Counsel for Nationwide filed a notice of appearance and denied representing Blackwell.Â  He also wrote a letter to counsel for the Pressleys specifically advising that he would take no further action, nor file an answer, until Blackwell was properly served.Â  
On July 23, 2002, the Pressleys filed a motion requesting an order allowing for service by publication.Â  By order dated July 31, 2002, the trial court granted the motion.Â  The order directed that publication be made in The Gaffney Ledger at least one time per week for three consecutive weeks.Â  The order further required the first publication be made within ten (10) days from the date of the order.Â  Publication did not begin, however, until September 18, 2002, and was not completed until October 2, 2002.Â  
Counsel for Blackwell subsequently filed an Answer raising the issues of, inter alia, improper venue and statute of limitations.Â  Venue was thereafter transferred to Cherokee County.Â  On June 30, 2003, Blackwell filed and served a motion for summary judgment.Â  By order filed November 13, 2003, the trial court granted the motion, finding the Pressleys failed to timely serve Blackwell.Â  The Pressleys appeal. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œSummary judgment is appropriate when it is clear there is no genuine issue of material fact and the conclusions and inferences to be drawn from the facts are undisputed.â€Â  McClanahan v. Richland County Council, 350 S.C. 433, 437, 567 S.E.2d 240, 242 (2002).Â  Additionally, in ruling on a motion for summary judgment, a reviewing court must view the evidence in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  Id. at 438, 567 S.E.2d at 242.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Statute of Limitations 
The Pressleys argue the trial court erred in granting summary judgment based on the expiration of the statute of limitations.Â  We disagree.
A plaintiff in a negligence action must serve the defendant within three years.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-530(5) (2005).Â  The statute of limitations may, however, be tolled.Â  See Rule 3, SCRCP; S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-20 (2005).Â  
At the time of the accrual of this action, Rule 3 of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure provided in part:

a)   Commencement:Â  A civil action is commenced by filing and service of a summons and complaint.
b)    Tolling of Statute of Limitations:Â  For the purpose of tolling any statute of limitations, an attempt to commence an action is equivalent to the commencement thereof when the summons and complaint are filed with the clerk of court and delivered for service to the sheriff . . . provided that actual service must be accomplished within a reasonable time thereafter.

Rule 3, SCRCP (Supp. 2002), amended effective April 27, 2004 (emphasis added).Â  
Effective May 24, 2002, a few days prior to the filing of this action, S.C. Code section 15-3-20(B) was amended to provide in part:Â  â€œA civil action is commenced when the summons and complaint are filed with the clerk of court if actual service is accomplished within one hundred twenty days after filing.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-20(B) (2005) (emphasis added).Â  
By amendment effective April 27, 2004, Rule 3 was likewise amended to provide:

a)      Commencement of civil action:Â 
A civil action is commenced when the summons and complaint are filed with the clerk of court if:
  
1)Â Â Â Â Â  the summons and complaint are served within the statute of limitations in any manner prescribed by law; or
2)Â Â Â Â Â  if not served within the statute of limitations, actual service must be accomplished not later than one hundred twenty days after filing.
  

Rule 3, SCRCP (emphasis added).Â  With this history in mind, we review the Pressleysâ€™ argument.
In interpreting Rule 3 prior to the amendment, South Carolina courts found service by publication five months after filing of the complaint was reasonable but service more than a year after filing was unreasonable.Â  Compare Ingle v. Whitlock, 282 S.C. 391, 318 S.E.2d 367 (1984) with Montgomery v. Mullins, 325 S.C. 500, 506, 480 S.E.2d 467, 470 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  â€œWhether or not an action has been accomplished within a reasonable period of time depends on the circumstances of the case.â€Â  Montgomery, 325 S.C. at 506, 480 S.E.2d at 470.Â  This decision is committed to the trial judgeâ€™s discretion, and will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Id.Â  
The accident in this case occurred on June 5, 1999, and the statute of limitations period expired on June 5, 2002.Â  The Pressleys attempted to take advantage of the Rule 3(b) tolling provision by delivering the summons and complaint to the Cherokee County Sheriffâ€™s Office.Â  However, the Sheriffâ€™s Office was unable to serve Blackwell, and actual service was not accomplished until publication was completed on October 2, 2002.Â  
Blackwell argues that section 15-3-20(B) mandated service within 120 days after the case is filed and this mandate applied to the Pressleys.Â  We find the amendment provides an indication of legislative intent that even prior to the amendment, a reasonable time would ordinarily be within 120 days.Â  We need not determine whether the 120-day test or the reasonable time test controls in this case, however, as we find neither test has been met.
The trial judge ruled that service was not accomplished within a reasonable time.Â  We find no abuse of discretion given the facts and circumstances of this case, including failure to accomplish service within 120 days and dilatoriness in commencing publication.Â  Given the totality of these circumstances and our standard of review, we will not disturb the trial courtâ€™s finding that service was not accomplished within a reasonable time.
Furthermore, counsel failed to comply with a direct order from the court.Â  The publication order required service to commence within ten days.Â  The first publication was not made until nearly forty days after this deadline had expired.Â  Counsel for the Pressleys did not communicate any hardship or difficulty to the court.Â  Accordingly, we affirm the trial courtâ€™s finding that this action is barred by the statute of limitations.
II.Â  Notice of Hearing
The Pressleys also contend their due process rights were violated because they were not provided with adequate notice of the hearing.Â  This issue was never raised to the trial court in a Rule 59(e) motion or in any other manner other than a letter of protest to the trial court.Â  Issues not raised to and ruled upon by the trial court are not preserved for appeal.Â  In Re McCracken, 346 S.C. 87, 551 S.E.2d 235 (2001) (â€œA constitutional claim must be raised and ruled upon to be preserved for appellate review.â€).Â  
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, the order on appeal is
 AFFIRMED.Â  
 SHORT, J., concurs.
ANDERSON, J., concurs in result only in a separate opinion.


ANDERSON, J. (concurring in result only):Â  I agree with the majority that summary judgment should be affirmed.Â  I write separately because the amendment to S.C. Code Ann. section 15-3-20, which took effect seven days before the Pressleys filed their action, controls the disposition of this case.Â 
I.Â  CHRONOLOGICAL DEVELOPMENT OF
SECTION 15-3-20 AND RULE 3
From the enactment of the 1976 Code until May 23, 2002, section 15-3-20 stated: â€œCivil actions can only be commenced within the periods prescribed in this Title after the cause of action shall have accrued, except when, in special cases, a different limitation is prescribed by statute.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. (1976).Â  
The 2002 version of Rule 3, SCRCP, provided:

(a) Â Â Â  Commencement.Â  A civil action is commenced by filing and service of a summons and complaint.
(b) Â Â Â  Tolling of Statute of Limitations.Â  For the purpose of tolling any statute of limitations, an attempt to commence an action is equivalent to the commencement thereof when the summons and complaint are filed with the clerk of court and delivered for service to the sheriff of the county in which defendant usually or last resided . . . ; provided that actual service must be accomplished within a reasonable time thereafter.Â  

Rule 3, SCRCP (2002) (emphasis added).Â  
Effective May 24, 2002, section 15-3-20 was amended to read:

(A) Â Â  Civil actions may only be commenced within the periods prescribed in this title after the cause of action has accrued, except when, in special cases, a different limitation is prescribed by statute.
(B)Â Â Â  A civil action is commenced when the summons and complaint are filed with the clerk of court if actual service is accomplished within one hundred twenty days after filing.

S.C. Code Ann. section 15-3-20 (2005) (emphasis added).Â  
Subsequent to the amendment to section 15-3-20, Rule 3 was changed.Â  The rule now reads:

 (a)Â Â Â Â  Commencement of civil action.Â  A civil action is commenced when the summons and complaint are filed with the clerk of court if:
(1)Â Â Â Â  the summons and complaint are served within the statute of limitations in any manner prescribed by law; or
(2)Â Â Â Â  if not served within the statute of limitations, actual service must be accomplished not later than one hundred twenty days after filing.

Rule 3, SCRCP (emphasis added).Â  The note to the 2004 amendment to Rule 3 officially reports that the changes effected â€œare intended to reflect the legislative intent expressed in Â§ 15-3-20 as amended by 2002 S.C. Act No. 281, Â§ 1.â€Â  (Emphasis added.)Â Â Â  
II.Â  PRINCIPLES OF STATUTORY CONSTRUCTION
The cardinal rule of statutory interpretation is to determine the intent of the legislature.Â  Georgia-Carolina Bail Bonds. v. County of Aiken, 354 S.C. 18, 579 S.E.2d 334 (Ct. App. 2003); see also Gordon v. Phillips Utils. Inc., 362 S.C. 403, ___, 608 S.E.2d 425, 427 (2005) (â€œThe primary purpose in construing a statute is to ascertain legislative intent.â€); Olson v. Faculty House of Carolina, Inc., 344 S.C. 194, 205, 544 S.E.2d 38, 44 (Ct. App. 2001) (â€œThe quintessence of statutory construction is legislative intent.â€).Â  All rules of statutory construction are subservient to the one that legislative intent must prevail if it can be reasonably discovered in the language used, and that language must be construed in the light of the intended purpose of the statute.Â  McClanahan v. Richland County Council, 350 S.C. 433, 567 S.E.2d 240 (2002); Ray Bell Constr. Co. v. Sch. Dist. of Greenville County, 331 S.C. 19, 501 S.E.2d 725 (1998); State v. Morgan, 352 S.C. 359, 574 S.E.2d 203 (Ct. App. 2002); State v. Hudson, 336 S.C. 237, 519 S.E.2d 577 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  
The legislatureâ€™s intent should be ascertained primarily from the plain language of the statute.Â  State v. Landis, 362 S.C. 97, 606 S.E.2d 503 (Ct. App. 2004); Morgan, 352 S.C. at 366, 574 S.E.2d at 206; Stephen v. Avins Constr. Co., 324 S.C. 334, 478 S.E.2d 74 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  The language must also be read in a sense which harmonizes with its subject matter and accords with its general purpose.Â  Hitachi Data Sys. v. Leatherman, 309 S.C. 174, 420 S.E.2d 843 (1992); Morgan, 352 S.C. at 366, 574 S.E.2d at 206; Hudson, 336 S.C. at 246, 519 S.E.2d at 582.Â  The courtâ€™s primary function in interpreting a statute is to ascertain the intent of the General Assembly.Â  Smith v. South Carolina Ins. Co., 350 S.C. 82, 564 S.E.2d 358 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  â€œOnce the legislature has made [a] choice, there is no room for the courts to impose a different judgment based upon their own notions of public policy.â€Â  South Carolina Farm Bureau Mut. Ins. Co. v. Mumford, 299 S.C. 14, 19, 382 S.E.2d 11, 14 (Ct. App. 1989).
If a statuteâ€™s language is unambiguous and clear, there is no need to employ the rules of statutory construction and this Court has no right to look for or impose another meaning.Â  Tilley v. Pacesetter Corp., 355 S.C. 361, 585 S.E.2d 292 (2003); Paschal v. State Election Commâ€™n, 317 S.C. 434, 454 S.E.2d 890 (1995); Cowan v. Allstate Ins. Co., 351 S.C. 626, 631, 571 S.E.2d 715, 717 (Ct. App. 2002); Olson, 344 S.C. at 207, 544 S.E.2d at 45; see also City of Camden v. Brassell, 326 S.C. 556, 561, 486 S.E.2d 492, 495 (Ct. App. 1997) (â€œWhere the language of the statute is clear and explicit, the court cannot rewrite the statute and inject matters into it which are not in the legislatureâ€™s language.â€).Â  When the terms of a statute are clear, the court must apply those terms according to their literal meaning.Â  Cooper v. Moore, 351 S.C. 207, 212, 569 S.E.2d 330, 332 (2002); Holley v. Mount Vernon Mills, Inc., 312 S.C. 320, 440 S.E.2d 373 (1994); Carolina Alliance for Fair Employment v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Labor, Licensing, & Regulation, 337 S.C. 476, 523 S.E.2d 795 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  What a legislature says in the text of a statute is considered the best evidence of the legislative intent or will. Bayle v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 344 S.C. 115, 542 S.E.2d 736 (Ct. App. 2001). The words of a statute must be given their plain and ordinary meaning without resorting to subtle or forced construction.Â  Durham v. United Companies Fin. Corp., 331 S.C. 600, 503 S.E.2d 465 (1998); Adkins v. Comcar Indus., Inc., 323 S.C. 409, 475 S.E.2d 762 (1996); Worsley Cos. v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 351 S.C. 97, 102, 567 S.E.2d 907, 910 (Ct. App. 2002); see also Timmons v. South Carolina Tricentennial Commâ€™n, 254 S.C. 378, 175 S.E.2d 805 (1970) (observing that where the language of the statute is clear and explicit, the court cannot rewrite the statute and inject matters into it that are not in the legislatureâ€™s language).Â  Under the plain meaning rule, it is not the courtâ€™s place to change the meaning of a clear and unambiguous statute.Â  Hodges v. Rainey, 341 S.C. 79, 533 S.E.2d 578 (2000); Bayle, 344 S.C. at 122, 542 S.E.2d at 739.
If the language of an act gives rise to doubt or uncertainty as to legislative intent, the construing court may search for that intent beyond the borders of the act itself.Â  Morgan, 352 S.C. at 367, 574 S.E.2d at 207; see also Wade v. Berkeley County, 348 S.C. 224, 229, 559 S.E.2d 586, 588 (2002) (â€œ[W]here a statute is ambiguous, the Court must construe the terms of the statute.â€). An ambiguity in a statute should be resolved in favor of a just, beneficial, and equitable operation of the law.Â  Hudson, 336 S.C. at 247, 519 S.E.2d at 582; Brassell, 326 S.C. at 561, 486 S.E.2d at 495; City of Sumter Police Depâ€™t v. One (1) 1992 Blue Mazda Truck, 330 S.C. 371, 498 S.E.2d 894 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  In construing a statute, the court looks to the language as a whole in light of its manifest purpose.Â  State v. Dawkins, 352 S.C. 162, 573 S.E.2d 783 (2002); Adams v. Texfi Indus., 320 S.C. 213, 464 S.E.2d 109 (1995); Brassell, 326 S.C. at 560, 486 S.E.2d at 494.
â€œA statute as a whole must receive a practical, reasonable, and fair interpretation consonant with the purpose, design, and policy of the lawmakers.Â  The real purpose and intent of the lawmakers will prevail over the literal import of the words.â€Â  Browning v. Hartvigsen, 307 S.C. 122, 125, 414 S.E.2d 115, 117 (1992); see also Georgia-Carolina Bail Bonds, 354 S.C. at 22, 579 S.E.2d at 336 (â€œA statute should be given a reasonable and practical construction consistent with the purpose and policy expressed in the statute.â€); Municipal Assâ€™n of South Carolina v. AT & T Communications of S. States, Inc., 361 S.C. 576, 606 S.E.2d 468 (2004) (observing that the language of a statute must be read in a sense which harmonizes with its subject matter and accords with its general purpose).Â  
Courts will reject a statutory interpretation which would lead to a result so plainly absurd that it could not have been intended by the legislature or would defeat the plain legislative intention.Â  Unisun Ins. Co. v. Schmidt, 339 S.C. 362, 529 S.E.2d 280 (2000); Kiriakides v. United Artists Communications, Inc., 312 S.C. 271, 440 S.E.2d 364 (1994).Â  A court should not consider a particular clause in a statute as being construed in isolation, but should read it in conjunction with the purpose of the whole statute and the policy of the law.Â  See Hinton v. South Carolina Dept. of Prob., Parole and Pardon Servs., 357 S.C. 327, 592 S.E.2d 335 (Ct. App. 2004), cert. granted (Jan. 12, 2005); Doe v. Roe, 353 S.C. 576, 578 S.E.2d 733 (Ct. App. 2003), cert. denied. 
III.Â  JUXTAPOSITION OF THE RULES OF
CIVIL PROCEDURE TO THE CODE OF LAWS 
Article V, section 4, of the South Carolina Constitution decrees: â€œThe Supreme Court shall make rules governing the administration of all the courts of the State.Â  Subject to the statutory law, the Supreme Court shall make rules governing the practice and procedure in all such courts.â€Â  In Stokes v. Denmark Emergency Medical Services, 315 S.C. 263, 267, 433 S.E.2d 850, 852 (1993), our supreme court explained, â€œThe clause â€˜subject to the statutory lawâ€™ establishes the intent to subordinate to the General Assembly the Courtâ€™s rulemaking power in regard to practice and procedure.â€Â  Accordingly, although the supreme court has wide latitude to regulate the procedures of South Carolinaâ€™s courts, the General Assembly retains a greater authority to govern the operation of our judicial system.
IV.Â  ANALYSIS
The Pressleys filed the action in the instant case on May 31, 2002â€”after the promulgation of the statutory amendment, but before the change in the rule.Â  Consequently, the procedural aspects of this case are governed by the 2002 version of Rule 3 and amended section 15-3-20.Â  
The 2002 form of Rule 3 provides that service may be proper so long as actual service is accomplished within a reasonable time after the summons and complaint are filed with the clerk of court and delivered to the sheriff.Â  However, section 15-3-20 plainly does away with a reasonable time analysis by providing actual service must be accomplished within 120 days after filing.Â  Our General Assembly drew a bold, bright, and unambiguous line.Â  This lucid and edictal change to section 15-3-20 leaves no room for equivocation over its meaning.Â  Indeed, the efficacy of amended 15-3-20 is proved by the note to new Rule 3 which expressly states the rule was revised to bring it into conformity with the legislatureâ€™s intent in altering the statute in 2002.Â Â Â  
The Pressleys did not meet the 120-day deadline.Â  The bill that amended section 15-3-20 provided: â€œThis act takes effect upon approval by the Governor and applies to causes of action filed on or after this actâ€™s effective date.â€Â  Act No. 281, 2002 S.C. Acts 2726.Â  Act No. 281 became law on May 24, 2002.Â  Indubitably, the amendment was in effect when the Pressleys filed their action on May 31, 2002.Â  Actual service was not complete until the final publication on October 2, 2002.Â  Compliance with section 15-3-20 would have required the Pressleys to accomplish service by September 28, 2002, 120 days after May 31.Â  Thus, because the Pressleys failed to satisfy the statute of limitations, summary judgment was properly granted. 
V.Â  CONCLUSION
The chronological evolution of the statute and rule reveals a judicial progression to the status of the mandatory provision in the statute: â€œA civil action is commenced when the summons and complaint are filed with the clerk of court if actual service is accomplished within one hundred twenty days after filing.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. section 15-3-20(B) (2005).Â  The applicability of precedent, statutory construction principles, and a commonsensical analysis bring me to the ineluctable conclusion that the statutory language is efficacious and controlling.Â  In contrariety to the majority opinion, I hold that section 15-3-20(B) is an absolute and mandatory revelation of legislative intent that a reasonable time is delimited by a calendar application of 120 days.Â  Section 15-3-20 creates a bright-line test.Â  In simplistic terms, the rule amendment by the South Carolina Supreme Court evidences a concurrent response to reflect the legislative intent expressed by the South Carolina General Assembly in the amendatory language encapsulated in section 15-3-20.Â

J. F. Cleckley & Co., 325 S.C. 327, 344, 479 S.E.2d 67, 75 (Ct. App. 1996) (â€œThe objection should be sufficiently specific to bring into focus the precise nature of the alleged error so that it can be reasonably understood by the trial judge.â€);Â  Gurganious v. City of Beaufort, 317 S.C. 481, 488, 484 S.E.2d 912, 916 (Ct. App. 1995) (holding a party may not present one ground at trial and then change his theory on appeal; the same ground argued on appeal must have been argued at trial).
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, HUFF, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA

Michael G. Phillips, Andre Sullivan, Tywanna Kithcart, Samuel Gallishaw, Latesia Brinson, Jameta Wheeler, Chasity McClam, Chasie McClam, Ramona Banks, Christopher Adams, Amithy Merrill, Mark Dudley, Reginald Ray, Sandy Rogers, Nicole Sims, Luciana White, Janell Branch, Chauncey Black, Gregory Gartrell, Tamara Elliott, Monifa Drayton, Talisha Brown, Nadya Brown, Randy Brantley, Keshia Oliver, Crystal Mack, Devonna McCray, Angela Holland, Willie S. Trappier, Delane Mitchell and Neva Gray, Appellants,

  v.
  South Carolina State University, Rheem Manufacturing Co., Inc., and Honeywell, Inc., Defendants, of whom Honeywell, Inc., is, Respondent.


   
  

Appeal From Orangeburg County
James C. Williams, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-320
Submitted March 1, 2005 â€“ Filed May 12, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Brenda Reddix-Smalls, of Columbia, for Appellants.
        Jeannine L. Lee and Patrick R. Martin, of Minneapolis, MN; and Phillip Florence and Thomas Gottshall, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: In this product liability case, Appellants are students of South Carolina State University (SCSU) who were injured when a water heater began emanating carbon monoxide.Â  Appellants brought an action against the university and the manufacturers of the water heater before settling these claims.Â  Honeywell, Inc., the supplier of one of the components of the hot water heater, remained as the lone defendant.Â  Appellants asserted numerous theories of liability and the trial judge granted summary judgment.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS

On August 29, 1998, a water heater issued toxic fumes into a dormitory that killed one student in an adjacent room and affected several other students.Â  Tests conducted shortly after the incident indicated concentrations of carbon monoxide were present in the room where the water heater was located and in the dormitory rooms in the immediate vicinity.Â  
Rheem Manufacturing Co., Inc. manufactured the water heater while SCSU installed and maintained it.Â  The water heater design included an energy saving damper that closed the flue opening when the water heater was not in operation.Â  The damper consisted of a metal flap at the top of the water heater that was designed to open prior to burner operation to allow the combustion products to vent.Â  Rheem manufactured the damper assembly.Â  The damper was attached by a rod to a damper actuator motor which powered the damper to open and close.Â  Honeywell supplied the actuator motor, a Honeywell model M892, and a small arrow coupler clip to Rheem.Â Â Â  
Because of the danger of carbon monoxide production, the damper assembly was required to have a backup mechanism to ensure that the damper opened when the water heater was on in case of motive power failure or deenergization of the vent damper device.Â  Although Honeywell also manufactured a complete damper assembly that incorporated such a failsafe mechanism, the D892, Rheem did not use this product.Â  Instead, Rheem designed its own damper assembly and incorporated only the M892 actuator motor from Honeywell.Â  
When Honeywell originally designed D892, it incorporated a return spring to pull the damper to a fully open position.[2]Â  The D892 was certified for compliance with applicable industry standards.Â  
Honeywell subsequently decided to sell the actuator motor separately to manufacturers who wanted to build their own damper assemblies.Â  The M892 was a motor that caused a ninety degree rotation of a shaft which was a standard item that could be used in a variety of applications.Â  Appellantsâ€™ expert testified that the M892 was â€œa proven product with a history of manufacture of around a hundred thousand unitsâ€ and that as a stand-alone component, it was â€œa functional motor that satisfie[d] the intent of [industry] specifications.â€Â  Appellantsâ€™ expert further agreed that the M892 by itself was safe.Â  
Â Because the M892 could be used to power a damper assembly, Honeywell provided a warning label notifying purchasers that the completed damper assembly would need a failsafe device to open the damper.Â  The original warning label specified a spring for this purpose, similar to the design of the D892.Â  The warning label was Honeywellâ€™s only means of insuring the safety of the final product.Â  
When Rheem designed its damper, however, Rheem elected not to use a spring.Â  Rheem made this decision in order to avoid using moving parts and because of concerns that the spring could be subject to corrosion or tampering and therefore elected to use a counterweight instead.Â  
During the design phase, Rheem and Honeywell discussed certain problems with the application.Â  One difficulty was that the damper, incorporating the Honeywell motor, would not close all the way.Â  Engineers from Rheem and Honeywell met and determined that Honeywellâ€™s motor was not at fault.Â  Instead, parts of the damper assembly were interfering with each other to prevent closure.Â  Later, Rheem requested that the warning label be changed to reflect its decision to use a counterweight.Â  Honeywell approved the change, realizing that alternate means of accomplishing the purpose served by the spring existed.Â  The warning labels shipped to Rheem called for a â€œreturn mechanismâ€ instead of a â€œreturn springâ€ to serve as a failsafe device.Â  
Once these problems were resolved, Honeywell approved the application.Â  Rheem then sought and obtained American Gas Association (AGA) certification of the complete water heater.Â  AGA used test data on the M892 from Honeywellâ€™s D892 certification to complete the test report.Â  Honeywell did not test the final damper assembly because the testing was performed by Rheem. 
Appellantsâ€™ experts attributed the release of the carbon monoxide to three main factors: (1) improper maintenance and installation of the water heater; (2) improper design of the water heater which allowed condensation to drip on the burner; and (3) incomplete venting due to a faulty damper assembly.Â  Since Rheem and SCSU are no longer parties to this action, the only remaining issues relate to the damper assembly.
When the responding public agencies arrived to test the water heater the morning after the incident, they saw SCSU employees leaving the utility room carrying duct tape and hand tools.Â  The responding officials were concerned because the utility room was supposed to have been a taped-off secure area.Â  SCSU employees admitted they found the damper assembly disconnected from the motor and tried unsuccessfully to reattach it with duct tape.Â  They could not connect the parts because a coupler was missing.Â  
Honeywellâ€™s expert testified that the damper assembly had been intentionally disconnected because the connecting rod was bent and the motors holding Honeywellâ€™s motor in place were either missing or loose.Â  With the motor disconnected, the damper was found in a half-open position, roughly two to three oâ€™clock, rather than a twelve oâ€™clock position.Â  
Appellantsâ€™ expert testified that the damper had been disconnected â€œ[w]ithin a couple hours of the incident.â€Â  He further testified that the damperâ€™s half-open position produced decreased draft, and was thus one of the contributing causes of the carbon monoxide production.Â  
The day after the incident occurred, SCSUâ€™s Police Department measured carbon monoxide levels in the dormitory rooms.Â  The results established the presence of the gas, but only in the immediate vicinity of the water heater.[3]Â  Police also found carbon monoxide levels on the outside of the building across from the water heater room.Â  Appellantsâ€™ expert testified that carbon monoxide could have spread throughout the building through the ventilation system. Â However, none of Appellantsâ€™ experts did any testing on SCSUâ€™s ventilation to verify their theories.Â  Additionally, one of their experts testified he could not opine that it was more probable than not that carbon monoxide spread throughout the building.Â  
The amended complaint alleges six causes of action against Honeywell, including negligence, intentional infliction of emotional distress, unfair trade practices, tortious interference with contract, product liability and breach of warranty claims.Â  After a lengthy discovery, Honeywell moved for summary judgment on all claims.Â  The trial court granted Honeywellâ€™s motion.Â  This appeal follows. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW

â€œSummary judgment is appropriate when it is clear there is no genuine issue of material fact and the conclusions and inferences to be drawn from the facts are undisputed.â€Â  McClanahan v. Richland County Council, 350 S.C. 433, 437, 567 S.E.2d 240, 242 (2002).Â  Additionally, in ruling on a motion for summary judgment, a reviewing court must view the evidence in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  Id. at 438, 567 S.E.2d at 242. 
LAW/ANALYSIS

I. Product Liability Claims
To establish a product liability claim under both negligence and strict liability theories, a plaintiff must show (1) that he was injured by the product; (2) that the product, at the time of the accident, was in essentially the same condition as when it left the hands of the defendant; and (3) that the injury occurred because the product was in a defective condition unreasonably dangerous to the user.Â  Allen v. Long Mfg. NC, Inc., 332 S.C. 422, 426, 505 S.E.2d 354, 356 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  Under a negligence theory, a plaintiff must additionally demonstrate that the defendant seller or manufacturer failed to exercise due care with respect to safety in the productâ€™s design.Â  Id. at 426-27, 505 S.E.2d at 356.Â  
A. Defective Design
Appellants first assert that Honeywellâ€™s M892 was defective due to a flaw in its design.Â  Honeywell defends on the ground that, as the component manufacturer of the M892 only, it should not be liable for the design flaws of the entire Rheem damper assembly.Â  Although Appellants claim that the M892 was defective, there is no evidence in the record that the M892 itself failed.Â  Appellantsâ€™ expert admitted that the M892, as a standalone unit, was safe.[4]Â  Therefore, the trial court correctly found that the M892 itself was not defective.
South Carolina courts have not addressed the liability of the manufacturer of a nondefective component for design defects in the final product.Â  â€œGenerally, a manufacturer of a component part is not liable for injuries caused by the component when it is incorporated into a finished product by a third party where the component in and of itself was not unreasonably dangerous at the time it left the component manufacturerâ€™s control.â€Â  63 Am. Jur. 2d Products Liability Â§ 147 (2004).
Furthermore, a component part manufacturer generally has no duty to analyze the safety of a completed product that incorporates its nondefective component part.Â  Childress v. Gresen Mfg. Co., 888 F.2d 45 (6th Cir. 1989).Â  Imposing such a duty would require component part manufacturers to guarantee the safety of other manufacturersâ€™ machinery.Â  Crossfield v. Quality Control Equip. Co., 1 F.3d 701, 704 (8th Cir. 1993).Â  
The only exception to this rule occurs when the component manufacturer substantially participates in the integration of the component into the design of the final product.Â  See Restatement (Third) of Torts: Products Liability Â§ 5(b)(1).Â  Courts usually determine whether the component manufacturer substantially participated in the final design by asking whether the seller had control over the design of the completed product.Â  See e.g. Jacobs v. E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., 67 F.3d 1219, 1242 (6th Cir. 1995).Â  A component manufacturer that merely designs a component to its buyerâ€™s specifications does not â€œsubstantially participateâ€ for products liability purposes.Â  Restatement (Third) of Torts: Products Liability Â§ 5 cmt. e.Â  Moreover, providing mechanical or technical services or advice concerning a component part does not, by itself, subject a component seller to liability.Â  Id.Â  
The record shows that Honeywellâ€™s engineers met with Rheemâ€™s engineers to discuss a problem that developed in pairing Honeywellâ€™s motor to Rheemâ€™s damper assembly.Â  Additionally, Rheem requested and received approval from Honeywell to use a counterweight and to change the warning label to acknowledge Rheemâ€™s application.Â  At most, this establishes that Honeywell knew of the intended use for the M892 and that Honeywell provided mechanical or technical services or advice.Â  Without more, Honeywell is not subject to liability for defects in Rheemâ€™s final damper assembly design, because Appellants have failed to provide any evidence that Honeywell had control over Rheemâ€™s choice of design. 
B. Inadequate Warning
Appellants next argue that Honeywell failed to provide an adequate warning.Â  South Carolina recognizes the principle that a seller of a dangerous product must provide an adequate warning to the user to prevent liability.Â  Allen at 427, 505 S.E.2d at 357.Â  However, we note that there is no evidence that the M892 was dangerous.Â  Additionally, it is undisputed that Rheem received notice of the warning requiring a spring because Rheem requested the change in the language on the warning label.
Even if this were not true, however, Honeywell would still not be liable.Â  Component parts manufacturers generally have no duty to warn end users of the potentially dangerous uses to which their products may be put.Â  Jacobs, 67 F.3d at 1236.Â  This would require speculation as to subsequent applications.Â  Id.Â  Moreover, any such duty is fulfilled by the sophisticated intermediary rule.Â  Under this rule, a component supplier is not required to provide a warning to end users if it is reasonable for the supplier to rely on the buyer to take precautions to protect end users.Â  Id. at 1240-41.Â  The same rule applies when the buyer is a large employer that knows or should know of the dangers to its employees inherent in the supplies it purchases.Â  Bragg v. Hi-Ranger, Inc., 319 S.C. 531, 550, 462 S.E.2d 321, 332 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  Rheem was a manufacturer of water heaters that was familiar with the need for a failsafe mechanism for its damper, and Honeywell reasonably relied on Rheem to provide an adequate warning to end users.Â  Accordingly, we hold that Appellantsâ€™ failure to warn claim fails as a matter of law.
C. Express or Implied Warranty
Our finding that the M892 was not defective disposes of Appellantsâ€™ warranty claims also.Â  Appellants assert that certification of the D892 with the AGA created an express warranty covering the M892 without providing any legal support for their theory whatsoever.[5]Â  The express warranty provided with the M892 was factually inapposite.Â  We note that the express warranty specifically and conspicuously disclaimed all other express or implied warranties as required by South Carolina Code section 36-2-316.Â  Appellantsâ€™ argument that section 36-2-318 prevents disclaimer of warranties is also without merit.Â  The reportersâ€™ comments to section 36-2-318 make clear that this section does not prevent disclaimers but is instead intended to abolish the privity defense.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 36-2-318, official cmt. 1 (2003).Â  Therefore, summary judgment for Honeywell on this issue was proper.
D. Negligence
Liability for negligence requires Appellants to show that Honeywell breached its duty to use due care in adopting a safe design.Â  Allen at 426, 505 S.E.2d at 356.Â  The trial court correctly found that Appellants failed to demonstrate that Honeywell had any knowledge of a problem with its M892 motor.Â  Honeywellâ€™s statement that it had no prior claims filed against it involving the M892 went unchallenged.Â  See Oglesby v. General Motors Corp., 190 F.3d 244, 252 (4th Cir. 1999) (finding summary judgment on the issue of negligence appropriate under South Carolina law when defendantâ€™s statement that it had no prior claims involving the part at issue went unchallenged).Â  In addition, Appellantsâ€™ expert admitted that the M892 by itself was safe, and there is no evidence that the unit in question failed.
Appellants further argue that subsequent modification does not preclude liability for the manufacturer.Â  However, the cases Appellants cite all involve situations in which the product was defective prior to the alteration.Â  See Small v. Pioneer Mach., Inc., 329 S.C. 448, 466, 494 S.E.2d 835, 844 (Ct. App. 1997) (finding that subsequent modifications did not causally contribute to the injury); Fleming v. Borden, Inc., 316 S.C. 452, 457, 450 S.E.2d 589, 592 (1994) (finding modification foreseeable because of defective design).Â  Subsequent modification cannot be used to impose liability on the manufacturer of a non-defective product. 
E. Proximate Cause
Appellantsâ€™ product liability claims also fail because they cannot prove proximate cause.Â  Proximate cause is an essential element in products liability claims, whether brought under strict liability, negligence, or warranty theories.Â  Small at 463, 494 S.E.2d at 842.Â  Proximate cause requires proof of both causation in fact and legal causation.Â  Causation in fact is proven by establishing the injury would not have occurred â€œbut forâ€ the defendantâ€™s negligence.Â  Legal cause is proven by establishing foreseeability.Â  Id. 
In this case, Appellants cannot show that Honeywellâ€™s actions were a â€œbut forâ€ cause of their injuries.Â  The trial court found that Honeywellâ€™s motor was disconnected from the damper assembly at the time the incident occurred.Â  Although on a summary judgment motion we must take all evidence in the light most favorable to the non-moving party, we find no evidence contradicting the trial judgeâ€™s finding.Â  
The only evidence Appellants offer in opposition is the ambiguous testimony of one of their experts, who testified that the damper had been disconnected â€œ[w]ithin a couple hours of the incident.â€Â  Appellants contend that their expert intended to say that the damper was disconnected from the motor after the accident.Â  However, the testimony of their expert that the half-open position of the damper caused the incident indicates that he meant the damper was disconnected before the incident occurred.Â  Another of Appellantsâ€™ experts testified that the disconnected damper would have eventually created a problem, but did not on this occasion because other factors caused the carbon monoxide buildup on the date in question.Â  
Intentionally disconnecting a safety feature breaks any causal link.Â  See Young v. Tide Craft, Inc., 270 S.C. 453, 242 S.E.2d 671 (1978) (holding that the boat manufacturer was not liable because a mechanicâ€™s action in splicing a steering cable broke the causal link); see also 63 Am. Jur. 2d Products Liability Â§ 39 (2004) (stating that a manufacturer is not liable when a third partyâ€™s alteration of the product amounts to a superceding cause of the injury).Â  No evidence suggests the damper was disconnected due to any problem with the motor.Â  Therefore, summary judgment was proper because Appellants cannot show proximate cause.[6]
II. Unfair Trade Practices Claim
Appellants next assert that the trial court erred in granting Honeywellâ€™s motion for summary judgment on their Unfair Trade Practices claim.Â  We disagree.Â  
Under the South Carolina Unfair Trade Practices Act (UTPA), any person suffering an ascertainable loss of money or real or personal property as a result of a defendantâ€™s unfair or deceptive practices may bring an action for damages.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 39-5-140 (1985).Â  In order to recover under UTPA, a plaintiff must demonstrate that (1) the defendant engaged in an unlawful trade practice; (2) the plaintiff suffered actual, ascertainable damages as a result of the defendantâ€™s use of the unlawful trade practice; and (3) the unlawful trade practice had an adverse impact on the public interest.Â  Id.; see also section 39-5-20.Â  An act is unfair under the UTPA when it is offensive to public policy or when it is immoral, unethical, or oppressive, and a deceptive practice is one that has a tendency to deceive.Â  Johnson v. Collins Enter. Co., Inc., 349 S.C. 613, 636, 564 S.E.2d 653, 665 (2002).Â  
The trial court properly granted summary judgment on Appellantsâ€™ UTPA claim.Â  There is no evidence of any immoral, unethical or oppressive conduct by Honeywell, or of any act tending to deceive.Â  The M892 was not defective and there is no evidence of any attempt to misrepresent its compliance with safety standards.Â  The fact that the AGA agreed to certify Rheemâ€™s damper using test data from Honeywellâ€™s certification of the D892 does not equate to a deceptive or unfair practice by Honeywell.Â  Moreover, since the Appellants cannot show evidence of repetition, there can be no adverse public impact.Â  No claims regarding the M892 have been filed prior to this case and Honeywell no longer manufactures this part.Â  
III. Intentional Infliction of Emotional Distress Claim
The trial court also properly granted summary judgment for Honeywell on Appellantsâ€™ intentional infliction of emotional distress claim.Â  The requirements for establishment of the tort are: 

  (1) the defendant intentionally or recklessly inflicted severe emotional distress, or knew that distress would probably result from his conduct; (2) the defendantâ€™s conduct was so extreme and outrageous that it exceeded all possible bounds of decency and was furthermore atrocious, and utterly intolerable in a civilized community; (3) the actions of the defendant caused the plaintiffâ€™s emotional distress; and (4) the emotional distress suffered by the plaintiff was so severe that no reasonable person could be expected to endure it. 

Gattison v. S.C. State College, 318 S.C. 148, 151-52, 456 S.E.2d 414, 416 (Ct. App. 1995).Â Â  A judge should not submit a claim of intentional infliction of emotional distress to the jury unless reasonable persons might differ on the issue.Â  Id.Â  Even unprofessional, inappropriate behavior by a defendant is insufficient.Â  Id. at 157, 456 S.E.2d at 419.
There is no evidence of any unprofessional or inappropriate behavior by Honeywell, much less conduct so extreme and outrageous as to exceed all possible bounds of decency.Â  Accordingly, we affirm on this issue as well. 
IV. Recusal of the Trial Judge
Finally, Appellants argue that the trial judge should have recused himself.Â  A trial judgeâ€™s refusal to disqualify himself will not be reversed on appeal absent evidence of judicial prejudice.Â  State v. Cheatham, 349 S.C. 101, 111, 561 S.E.2d 618, 624 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  â€œIt is not enough for a party seeking disqualification to simply allege bias. Â The party must show some evidence of bias.Â  Furthermore, the alleged bias must be personal, as distinguished from judicial, in nature.â€Â  Id. (citations omitted). 
Counsel for Appellants assert that the trial judge showed a lack of judicial decorum and open hostility toward her during the motions hearing held on September 24, 2002.Â  At that hearing, which was held the day before the deadline for the fourth scheduling order, counsel for Appellants had moved to compel certain discovery.Â  Appellantsâ€™ counsel believed that Honeywell and Rheem were â€œin bed togetherâ€ and demanded repeatedly that Honeywell produce documents to substantiate this theory.Â  The trial judge found that all of the records that existed had already been produced.Â  Appellantsâ€™ counsel had requested information about â€œcomponent partsâ€ of the M892, apparently confounding the M892 with the D892, which was not used in Rheemâ€™s damper assembly.Â  The trial judge explained this to Appellantâ€™s counsel and denied the motion.Â  Nonetheless, Honeywell was ordered to produce any relevant records that had not yet been produced.Â  
Â We find no evidence of personal or prejudicial bias in the record.Â  The trial judge simply sought to prevent waste of judicial resources by cutting short Appellantsâ€™ counselâ€™s continued efforts to make arguments that were clearly based on a misapprehension of the facts.Â  The trial judge informed Appellantsâ€™ counsel that he had carefully reviewed the documents before making the ruling.Â  We note that the trial judge even attempted to reconcile any hard feelings produced as a result of this exchange.Â  
We hold that the trial judge did not abuse his discretion in denying Appellantsâ€™ motion to recuse.Â  We have reviewed Appellantsâ€™ remaining grounds for appeal and find them to be without merit. 
CONCLUSION

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  We hold that Appellants have failed to establish a products liability claim.Â  The M892 was not defective, and we decline to impose liability on a component manufacturer for design defects in the products into which component parts are incorporated.Â  Additionally, Honeywellâ€™s warning was adequate and, in any case, any duty to warn was fulfilled when Rheem, a sophisticated purchaser, received notice of the need for a return mechanism.Â  Moreover, Appellants cannot show proximate cause on any of their products liability claims.Â  Appellantsâ€™ warranty and negligence claims are without merit.Â  Likewise, the UTPA and intentional infliction of emotional distress claims lack any support from the record.Â  Summary judgment for Honeywell was therefore proper.Â  
AFFIRMED. 
ANDERSON, BEATTY, and SHORT, JJ., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Appellants erroneously assert that the M892 required a return spring as a failsafe mechanism.Â  The D892 damper assembly utilized a return spring.Â  The M892 was simply a motor (the actuator motor from the D892 damper assembly, sold separately) which Rheem bought and incorporated into its damper design.Â Â  
[3] The test results demonstrated the presence of carbon monoxide in rooms 228-233 and 128-137.Â  Of the Appellants, only two were in rooms testing positive for carbon monoxide at the time of the incident. 
[4] This expert attempted to disclaim this admission in a later deposition.Â  However, the disclaimer is ineffective because it essentially offers a legal opinion that Honeywellâ€™s participation in Rheemâ€™s final damper renders Honeywell liable.Â  See Kirkland v. Peoples Gas Co., 269 S.C. 431, 434, 237 S.E.2d 772, 773 (1977) (excluding expert testimony as to issues of law). 
[5] Appellants also assert that Rheemâ€™s certification of compliance sticker on the water heater created an express warranty by Honeywell.Â  Appellants offer no legal basis for this theory. 
[6] We also note that Appellantsâ€™ expert testimony offered to show exposure to carbon monoxide was based on speculation rather than hard test data.Â  None of the experts had actually visited the site of the incident.Â  Thus, Appellants have failed to demonstrate proximate cause for this reason also.Â  See Oglesby at 249 (â€œ[A] plaintiff may not prevail in a products liability case by relying on the opinion of an expert unsupported by any evidence such as test data or relevant literature in the field.â€).Â Â
