THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Dana Rice Ramsey,       
Respondent-Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Russell Wayne Ramsey,       
Appellant-Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Anderson County
Barry W. Knobel, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-321
Submitted April 1, 2005 â€“ Filed May 12, 2005

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED


  
    
      
W. Patrick Yon, of Anderson, for Appellant-Respondent.
J. Franklin McClain, of Anderson, and Roxy Rae Beagley, of Clemson, for Respondent-Appellant.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this cross appeal, Russell Wayne Ramsey (Father) appeals the family courtâ€™s order modifying visitation with his children.Â  Dana Rice Ramsey (Mother) appeals the portion of the family courtâ€™s order awarding Father extensive visitation, requiring Mother to reimburse Fatherâ€™s travel expenses, suspending Fatherâ€™s child support obligation during summer visitation, and denying Mother attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand.[1]Â Â  
FACTS
In 1999, Mother and Father divorced.Â  The parties reached a voluntary agreement regarding custody of their two children, Travis and Lauren, which the family court incorporated into its order.Â  The agreement granted Mother primary custody of the children, and granted Father specific visitation that included alternate weekends, holidays, spring breaks, and two afternoons each weekday from 5:30 p.m. to 7:30 p.m.Â  
In June 2001, Mother moved with the children from Anderson to Bluffton.Â  Prior to moving, Mother sent Father several letters indicating her desire to be closer to her parents in part because her father had reoccurring bladder cancer.Â  Mother offered Father additional visitation with the children to compensate for the four hours of midweek visitation that would be impossible due to the distance.Â  Father refused to modify the midweek visitation schedule, so Mother filed this action to modify the visitation order.Â  Father answered and counterclaimed for custody of the two children plus attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  
By final order, the family court denied Fatherâ€™s request for custody of the children, and modified the visitation schedule to accommodate Motherâ€™s move to Bluffton.Â  The family court increased Fatherâ€™s summer visitation from three weeks to five weeks, permitted three of the weeks to be consecutive, and eliminated Fatherâ€™s support obligation during these five weeks.Â  The family court further provided that Father could visit the children in Bluffton whenever he wished as long as he provided Mother with at least ten days advance notice, and ordered that Mother â€œshall fully cooperate in accommodating this visitation request.â€Â  In order to defray Fatherâ€™s travel expenses if he stayed in a hotel while in Bluffton, the family court ordered Mother to reimburse Father $50 per day for a maximum of $150.Â  This cross-appeal follows.Â  
 STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, we have jurisdiction to find the facts in accordance with our own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Bannen v. Bannen, 286 S.C. 24, 26, 331 S.E.2d 379, 380 (Ct. App. 1989).Â  However, this broad scope of review does not require us to disregard the family courtâ€™s findings.Â  Stevenson v. Stevenson, 276 S.C. 475, 477, 279 S.E.2d 616, 617 (1981).Â Â  Nor must we ignore the fact that the trial judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.Â  Murdock v. Murdock, 338 S.C. 322, 328, 526 S.E.2d 241, 245 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  In the absence of a clear abuse of discretion, the trial courtâ€™s order limiting visitation rights will not be disturbed on appeal. Nash v. Byrd, 298 S.C. 530, 536, 381 S.E.2d 913, 916 (Ct. App. 1989)
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Fatherâ€™s Appeal
Father argues the family court erred in modifying the prior custody order by changing Fatherâ€™s visitation schedule without making a specific finding of fact that a change in circumstances had occurred subsequent to the entry of the original order and in finding the move to Bluffton was in the childrenâ€™s best interests.Â  We disagree.
The controlling consideration when awarding visitation, is the welfare and best interest of the child.Â  Woodall v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 12, 471 S.E.2d 154, 158 (1996).Â  The guiding standard for modification for visitation is whether or not a change in circumstances occurred subsequent to the entry of the decree.Â  Ingold v. Ingold, 304 S.C. 316, 320, 404 S.E.2d 35, 37 (Ct. App. 1991).Â  â€œA change in circumstances justifying a change in visitation of a child simply means that sufficient facts have been shown to warrant the conclusion that the best interests of the child would be served by the change.â€Â  Pitt v. Olds, 333 S.C. 478, 481, 511 S.E.2d 60, 61 (1999).Â Â  Additionally, â€œthe court may not issue an order which prohibits a custodial parent from moving his residence to a location within the State unless the court finds a compelling reason or unless the parties have agreed to such a prohibition.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-420(30) (Supp. 2004).Â  
Although the court did not make a specific finding that a material change in circumstances had occurred to warrant modifying the visitation order, the family courtâ€™s order clearly changed Fatherâ€™s visitation because Motherâ€™s move to Bluffton with the children made the midweek visitation impossible.Â  Father argues Motherâ€™s knowledge that her father was suffering from reoccurring bouts of bladder cancer prior to the parties divorce prevents a finding the change in circumstances occurred subsequent to the entry of the original visitation order.Â  However, Mother testified she contemplated moving to Bluffton only after the divorce to help with her fatherâ€™s care and because she began to feel â€œaloneâ€ as she had no family in the area.Â  Moreover, the substantial change in circumstances, Motherâ€™s move with the children to Bluffton, occurred more than a year after the entry of the decree. Â Â Â Â 
Additionally, the family court made extensive findings in determining the move to Bluffton and subsequent modification of the visitation order was in the childrenâ€™s best interests.Â  The court found Motherâ€™s testimony and the guardian ad litemâ€™s report credible.Â  Mother indicated the children were excelling in school, participating in extracurricular activities, developing a wide circle of new friends, and experienced no negative effects due to the move to Buffton.Â  The guardian ad litem reported the children â€œwere happy in Blufftonâ€ and appeared â€œto be thriving in their current environment.â€Â  Mother has a greater income in Bluffton and a wide network of support from friends and family.Â  The family court found the move improved the general quality of life for Mother and the children.Â  Based upon the evidence presented in this case, we conclude the family court did not abuse its discretion in finding the move to Bluffton was in the childrenâ€™s best interests.Â  Accordingly, we find no error in the family courtâ€™s decision to modify the visitation order.Â Â Â Â  
II.Â  Motherâ€™s appeal
Mother argues the family court erred by modifying the visitation schedule to allow Father to visit the children in Bluffton whenever he wished as long as he provided Mother with at least ten days advance notice.Â  We remand this issue.
â€œThe issue of visitation is within the sound discretion of the family court and its findings will not be disturbed absent an abuse of that discretion.â€ Hyde v. Hyde, 302 S.C. 280, 281, 395 S.E.2d 186, 187 (Ct. App. 1990).Â  At the hearing, Father testified the loss of his weekday visitation prevented him from spending quality time with the children and from being involved in their day-to-day lives.Â  Before the children moved to Bluffton, Father picked the children up from school, attended baseball games, and took the children to the library or the park during the week.Â  In an attempt to foster an enduring father-child relationship in spite of the geographical distance, the family court provided Father with the opportunity to spend extended time with the children.Â  The family court ordered:

In the event the father wishes to travel to Bluffton, South Carolina to visit with the children (a) during periods other than those designated above, or (b) during these designated holiday periods, he shall provide the mother with at least 10 days advance notice of his intentions, and the mother shall fully cooperate in accommodating this visitation request.

Although we understand the family courtâ€™s intent in awarding Father additional visitation, we find the language of the order is not specific enough for us to determine whether the decision constituted an abuse of discretion.Â  Therefore, we remand the issue to the family court for a more definite ruling, including a more explicit statement regarding when Father may visit and how he must give notice.
Mother argues the family court erred by requiring Mother to reimburse Father at the rate of $50 per day with a maximum of $150 anytime he wishes to travel to Bluffton to exercise visitation.Â  We agree.
Our review of the record indicates Father has sufficient income to pay for any travel expenses incurred by exercising his visitation rights.Â  Father has a gross monthly income of $3,680.85, and Mother has a gross monthly income of $2,463.Â  Mother facilitated Fatherâ€™s visitation by exchanging the children at a halfway point between Bluffton and Anderson, and her parents offered to vacate their home so Father may stay there when he wishes to spend the night in Bluffton.Â  Mother also paid for the children to fly to Anderson to visit Father.Â  Moreover, the family court found although â€œFather testified that this current visitation arrangement has been financially taxing on him . . . both parties have the financial wherewithal to pay for any transportation costs.â€Â  Based upon these facts, we find the family court erred in ordering Mother to pay Fatherâ€™s travel expenses.Â Â Â Â  
Mother contends the family court erred by expanding Fatherâ€™s summer visitation from three weeks to five weeks and providing that three of the five weeks could be consecutive.Â  We disagree.Â  
As iterated above, the paramount consideration when awarding visitation is the best interest of the child, and the family courtâ€™s findings will not be disturbed absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Woodall at 12, 471 S.E.2d at 154.Â  At the hearing before the family court, Father testified the loss of his weekday visitation had affected his relationship with his children.Â  Father also testified his weekend visitation was adversely affected when the children moved because he spent approximately three hours driving the children to and from Anderson.Â  We agree with the family courtâ€™s finding it is impossible to foresee whether any visitation arrangement will be successful in maintaining a successful relationship between Father and the children.Â  As such, we find no abuse of discretion in the family courtâ€™s decision to expand Fatherâ€™s summer visitation so he can spend quality time with the children.
Mother argues the family court erred by suspending Fatherâ€™s child support obligation during his five weeks of summer visitation.Â  We disagree.
â€œChild support decisions are addressed to the sound discretion of the family court and will not be disturbed absent an abuse of discretion.â€Â  Engle v. Engle, 343 S.C. 444, 448, 539 S.E.2d 712, 714 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  In the case sub judice, the family court suspended Fatherâ€™s child support obligation only during the summer visitation period.Â  Because the children will visit with Father for an extended period of time, Mother will be relieved of expenses she would typically incur for food and other incidentals.Â  Additionally, the family court is within its discretion to adjust Fatherâ€™s child support obligation to help offset the higher cost of exercising visitation.Â  See Rice v. Rice, 335 S.C. 449, 466, 517 S.E.2d 220, 229 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  Accordingly, we find no abuse of discretion in the family courtâ€™s decision to shift expenses to Father by suspending his child support payments during the summer visitation.Â  
Mother argues the family court erred by failing to award her attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  We disagree.
â€œOrdinarily, the award of attorney fees lies within the sound discretion of the trial court and will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.â€ McElveen v. McElveen, 332 S.C. 583, 601, 506 S.E.2d 1, 10 (Ct. App. 1998). The factors to be considered in awarding reasonable attorney fees and costs include: (1) the nature, extent, and difficulty of the case; (2) the time necessarily devoted to the case; (3) the professional standing of counsel; (4) the contingency of compensation; (5) the beneficial results obtained; and (6) the customary legal fees for similar services.Â  Glasscock v. Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 161, 403 S.E.2d 313, 315 (1991).Â  In deciding whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees, the family court should consider the partiesâ€™ ability to pay their own fees, the beneficial results obtained by counsel, the respective financial conditions of the parties, and the effect of the fee on each partyâ€™s standard of living.Â  E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 476-77, 415 S.E.2d 812, 816 (1992).
Mother argues the family court should have awarded attorneyâ€™s fees to her because she attempted to negotiate a settlement with Father prior to filling the action, she obtained beneficial results, and Father had a greater ability to pay the fee.Â  However, Mother and Father each achieved beneficial results, and each party had the ability to pay his or her own fees.Â  Therefore, we find no abuse of discretion in the family courtâ€™s decision to deny attorneyâ€™s fees to both parties.Â Â Â  
CONCLUSION
We affirm the family courtâ€™s decision to modify the visitation order.Â  However, we remand the portion of the order granting Father unlimited visitation rights for a more definite statement of the partiesâ€™ respective rights and responsibilities, and reverse the portion of the order requiring Mother to pay Fatherâ€™s travel expenses.Â  We affirm the family courtâ€™s decision to award Father five weeks of summer visitation and to suspend his child support obligation during that time.Â  Additionally, we find no abuse of discretion in the family courtâ€™s decision to deny Mother attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, and REMANDED.Â Â Â  
ANDERSON, BEATTY, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA

Submitted May 1, 2005 â€“ Filed May 13, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Kenneth C. Porter, of Greenville, for Appellant.
William B. Chisholm, of Greenville, Pro Se Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Susan Chisholm appeals a family court order reversing a previous order, which required that William Chisholmâ€™s child support payments be paid through the court.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
William and Susan Chisholm were divorced by order of Judge R. Kinard Johnson, Jr., dated April 4, 2003.Â  William was ordered to make child support payments in the amount of $173.54 per week.Â  The order also stated, â€œIn the event the Father is late by more than three (3) days, then upon Affidavit of Mother, all future payments shall be made through the Family Court with the imposition of 5% court costs.â€Â  On October 28, 2003, Susan swore out an affidavit stating William had failed to pay child support as ordered and had been late by more than three days.Â  She then requested all future payments be made through the family court.Â  The next day, Susanâ€™s attorney sent a letter to Williamâ€™s attorney complaining that William had not paid child support due on October 17, 2003 and that he had deducted $32.81 from the child support payment due on October 24, 2003.Â  The letter further specified that counsel would proceed with a contempt action on the delinquent payment and improper deduction if they were not paid within five days.Â  It is uncontested that William then paid the amount of the deduction and another complete child support payment.Â  However, William contends he had previously attempted to pay the October 17, 2003 payment by delivering a check to Susanâ€™s residence.Â  
On October 30, 2003, based solely upon the affidavit, Judge Robert Jenkins ordered child support payments be made through the family court.Â  However, after hearing a motion for relief pursuant to Rule 60, SCRCP, the court reversed.Â  On January 13, 2004, the court found it was neither necessary nor equitable to require payment be made through the family court.Â  Judge Jenkins determined that either the payment was not late, or else it was excusable.Â  Therefore, he set aside his own order of October 30, 2003.Â  Susan appeals.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, we may find facts in accordance with our own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Emery v. Smith, 361 S.C. 207, 213, 603 S.E.2d 598, 601 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  However, this broad scope of review does not require us to disregard the family courtâ€™s findings.Â  Bowers v. Bowers, 349 S.C. 85, 91, 561 S.E.2d 610, 613 (Ct. App. 2002); Badeaux v. Davis, 337 S.C. 195, 202, 522 S.E.2d 835, 838 (Ct. App. 1999). Nor must a reviewing court ignore the fact the trial judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.Â  Murdock v. Murdock, 338 S.C. 322, 328, 526 S.E.2d 241, 245 (Ct. App. 1999).
LAW AND DISCUSSION
Susan argues the family court erred by vacating the order requiring payment through the family court and by failing to award attorney fees.Â  We disagree.
Susan points to language in the divorce decree that clearly and unambiguously states if William is late in child support payments by more than three days, upon motion of Susan, all future payments must be made through the family court.Â  She argues Judge Jenkinsâ€™ actions impermissibly modified this language in violation of the long standing rule that one judge may not overrule another judge of the same court.Â  See Charleston County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Father, 317 S.C. 283, 288, 454 S.E.2d 307, 310 (1995).Â  
Initially, we note that Judge Jenkins did not overrule Judge Johnsonâ€™s divorce order.Â  Rather, Judge Jenkins found the disputed payment either was not late or was excusable.Â  Thus, through the order dated January 13, 2004, Judge Jenkins set aside his own previous order of October 30, 2003, which had required William to make child support payments through the court. 
A review of the record shows that William contended he did pay the child support due October 17, 2003 within the allowed time.Â  Additionally, when it was brought to his attention that Susan did not receive the check, he corrected the problem.Â  Any delay might be attributed to Susan, as she apparently would not allow William to give her the check directly, but â€œpreferred [he] place the child support check in a zip lock sandwich bag, with a weight, and throw it toward the front of [Susanâ€™s] residence.â€Â  The peculiarity of this manner of delivery required by Susan made a lost child support payment almost inevitable.Â  
The other failure is the fact William deducted amounts totaling $32.81, which he directly paid for the support of his child, from the child support payment.Â  When Susan, through counsel, objected to this deduction, William promptly paid this amount.Â  Though this deduction was in error, it seems to have simply been a misunderstanding, which was subsequently corrected.Â  The family court deemed it unduly harsh to require payment through the court and the required a 5% handling fee, based solely on a deduction that was promptly corrected.
The family court specifically found no indication of previous delinquencies and no credible indication that child support payments needed to be paid through the court for them to be paid properly.Â  As the trial court said, the issue of the October 17, 2003 payment is â€œsimply one partyâ€™s statement versus that of the other party.â€Â  We do not find error in the family courtâ€™s refusal to require payment through the court for what was at most a technical violation that was corrected when brought to Williamâ€™s attention.
Accordingly, we affirm Judge Jenkinsâ€™ order of January 13, 2004, which set aside his previous order of October 30, 2003.Â  The provisions of the original divorce decree remain in full force and effect and are not modified by either of Judge Jenkinsâ€™ orders, or by this opinion.Â Â  
CONCLUSION
For the reasons discussed above, the order of the family court is 
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, STILWELL, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

PER CURIAM: In this workersâ€™ compensation action, the single commissioner determined that Thomas P. Bush was permanently and totally disabled as a result of an on-the-job injury to his back.Â  An appellate panel of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission (the commission) reversed the finding of the single commissioner, holding Bush was entitled only to a twenty percent permanent partial disability.Â  The circuit court affirmed, and Bush appeals.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
Thomas P. Bush injured his back during the course and scope of his employment as a heavy equipment mechanic with Pioneer Machinery on January 12, 2001.[2]Â  Bush sought treatment at Doctorâ€™s Care on January 16, 2001, complaining of resulting back and leg pain.Â  The attending doctor diagnosed Bush as suffering from a â€œlumbar strainâ€ and prescribed physical therapy and pain medication.Â  Bush returned to work the following day.Â  
Bush subsequently sought treatment at Midlands Orthopedics.Â  After evaluating an MRI, Dr. David Redmond diagnosed Bush as having a â€œwork-related injury with compression fracture L3 in a gentlemen with probably [sic] osteoporosis associated with steroid use in treatment of ulcerative colitisâ€ and determined Bush was able to perform â€œlight dutyâ€ work.Â  Dr. Ross Lynch, also of Midlands Orthopedics, separately examined Bush diagnosing â€œa compression fracture L3 minimal, probably steroid inducedâ€ and possible osteoporosis.Â  Dr. Lynch recommended a bone density test.Â  After the results of the bone density test, Dr. Lynch reaffirmed his diagnosis as â€œa compression fracture L3 minimal, probably steroid induced.â€Â  
After approximately eight months of treatment, Dr. Redmond released Bush at maximum medical improvement.Â  He assigned Bush a 5% whole person impairment rating with a 25% impairment rating to his spine.Â  Moreover, Dr. Redmond noted Bush was able to perform at light physical capacity level and could work with restrictions.Â  After Dr. Redmond released Bush, Dr. Lynch converted the whole person permanent rating to 6.6% and noted because of Bushâ€™s osteoporosis, â€œa permanent light duty status is probably best for him.â€ 
At the hearing, Bush countered the testimony of Dr. Redmond and Dr. Lynch with a non-physician counselor, Dr. William Stewart, in support of his contention of permanent total disability.Â  Dr. Stewart testified no â€œreasonable stable market exists or will exist for the types of services Mr. Bush is physically, educationally, or vocationally capable of performing/providing.â€Â  Based on this testimony, the single commissioner awarded Bush permanent total disability benefits.Â  
The commission reversed, finding the evidence only supported a finding that Bushâ€™s work-related injuries were limited to a lumbar strain and that the compression fracture at L3 was not caused by the work-related injury but rather was caused by osteoporosis resulting from his steroid use for treatment of his ulcerative colitis.Â  The circuit court affirmed the commission.Â  This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Bush alleges the circuit court and commission erred in reversing the single commissionerâ€™s finding that he is permanently and totally disabled as a result of the work-related injury of January 12, 2001.Â  We disagree.
The South Carolina Administrative Procedures Act applies to appeals from decisions of the commission.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 134-35, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981).Â  In an appeal from the commission, neither this court nor the circuit court may substitute its judgment for that of the commission as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact but may reverse when the decision is affected by an error of law.Â  Corbin v. Kohler Co., 351 S.C. 613, 617, 571 S.E.2d 92, 95 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  â€œAny review of the commissionâ€™s factual findings is governed by the substantial evidence standard.â€Â  Lockridge v. Santens of Am., Inc., 344 S.C. 511, 515, 544 S.E.2d 842, 844 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Accordingly, we limit review to deciding whether the commissionâ€™s decision is unsupported by substantial evidence or is controlled by some error of law.Â  Corbin, 351 S.C. at 617, 571 S.E.2d at 95.Â  
â€œSubstantial evidence is evidence that, in viewing the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the same conclusion that the full commission reached.â€Â  Lockridge, 344 S.C. at 515, 544 S.E.2d at 844.Â  â€œThe â€˜possibility of drawing two inconsistent conclusions from the evidence does not prevent an administrative agencyâ€™s finding from being supported by substantial evidence.â€™â€Â  Lee v. Harborside CafÃ©, 350 S.C. 74, 78, 564 S.E.2d 354, 356 (Ct. App. 2002) (quoting Palmetto Alliance, Inc. v. South Carolina Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n, 282 S.C. 430, 432, 319 S.E.2d 695, 696 (1984)).
Here, substantial evidence exists to support the commissionâ€™s finding that Bushâ€™s work-related injury was limited to a lumbar strain and that his L3 compression fracture was steroid induced.Â  Bush admittedly took steroids to treat his ulcerative colitis.Â  According to the testimony of Dr. Redmond and Dr. Lynch, the steroids caused Bush to develop the osteoporosis that led to the compression fracture.Â  Both of these orthopedists concluded Bush could perform light work with some limitations, and neither assigned more than a small percentage of permanent impairment.Â  We do note the evidence in support of Bushâ€™s claim, but it is not our province to weigh the evidence.Â  The commission acted well within its authority in assigning weight to the evidence from the two evaluating orthopedists to support its finding. 
CONCLUSION
Because substantial evidence exists to support the commissionâ€™s finding, the order of the circuit court is
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, HUFF, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

title: Griffin v. White Oak Properties
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(1), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Shirley J. Griffin and Henry R. Griffin, and Jacquelyn G. Burke and Michael J. Burke,
Respondents,
v.
White Oak Properties, LLC, Eugene Grissom McDonald, III, a/k/a Gris McDonald, and Home Shop Realty Company, Defendants, of whom White Oak Properties, LLC, Eugene Grissom McDonald, III, a/k/a Gris McDonald are
Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
L. Casey Manning, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-337
Heard March 8, 2005 â€“ Filed May 18, 2005

AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED


  
    
      
Stevens B. Elliot of Columbia, for Appellants.
Clifford O. Koon, Paul D. de Holczer and Mary Frances Gibson, all of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.:Â  White Oak Properties, LLC, and Eugene Grissom McDonald, III, (collectively â€œSellersâ€) appeal from an award of attorneyâ€™s fees in favor of Shirley and Henry Griffin and Jacquelyn and Michael Burke (collectively â€œPurchasersâ€) on their breach of contract action. We affirm as modified.
FACTS
The Griffins purchased real estate from White Oak and McDonald for $122,000.Â  The property was to be used as a residence by Jacquelyn and Michael Burke, their daughter and son-in-law.Â  Shortly after moving into the home, the Burkes noticed certain defects, including a defective foundation.Â  Purchasers sued Sellers, and Home Shop Realty, a real estate brokerage firm, alleging breach of the contract for sale, fraud, breach of contract accompanied by a fraudulent act, negligent misrepresentation, civil conspiracy, and a violation of the South Carolina Unfair Trade Practices Act.Â  
The causes of action were submitted to the jury through a special verdict form.Â  The jury denied all of Purchasersâ€™ causes of action, except breach of contract.Â  Through the special verdict form, the jury found Sellers breached the contract for the purchase of the home and that Sellers should take the home back and return the purchase money to Purchasers.Â  The jury did not award any other damages.Â  
Purchasers filed a motion for attorneyâ€™s fees, alleging that the contract for sale provided for â€œreasonable attorneyâ€™s fees.â€Â  They alleged that their attorney â€œhandled the proceeding under a contingency agreement and one-third of the award under the verdict (the return of the $122,000 purchase money for the home),â€ $40,626, would be reasonable.Â  At the hearing, Sellers argued that a contingency agreement was unreasonable because the jury awarded rescission and therefore, no damages were awarded.Â  Sellers also asked the court to carefully examine the attorneyâ€™s fees based on the amount of time and items charged by Purchasersâ€™ counsel because â€œwe just feel like that [sic] itâ€™s exorbitant.â€Â  
Through an â€œOrder Dealing with Post-trial Motions,â€ the trial judge granted Purchasersâ€™ motion for attorneyâ€™s fees in the amount of $40,626.Â  Sellers filed a Rule 59(e) motion, arguing the award based on a contingency fee was unreasonable because Purchasers did not recover $122,000.Â  In their motion, Sellers also urged the court to award fees based on the hourly rate submitted by Purchasersâ€™ counsel, including only fees â€œwhich can be specifically accounted forâ€ and â€œdeemed appropriate.â€Â  The trial judge made no ruling on Sellersâ€™ Rule 59(e) motion.Â  Sellers appeal the award of attorneyâ€™s fees.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Sellers concede Purchasers were entitled to an award of attorneyâ€™s fees, but challenge the award as excessive.Â  Specifically, they argue the award was excessive considering the remedy the jury provided to Purchasers.Â  While the jury found in favor of Purchasers on the breach of contract cause of action, the jury specifically stated that no damages were awarded and found Sellers must take the home back and return the purchase money to Purchasers.Â  Thus, the juryâ€™s verdict left the parties in the same position they were in prior to the sale.Â  We agree with Sellers, and find the trial judgeâ€™s award of attorneyâ€™s fees based on the contingency fee agreement to be excessive.Â  
â€œThe amount of attorneyâ€™s fees to be awarded in a particular case is within the discretion of the trial judge provided the award is reasonable.â€
    Baron Data Systems, Inc. v. Loter,  297 S.C. 382, 385-86, 377 S.E.2d 296, 298 (1989).Â  In determining a reasonable award of attorneyâ€™s fees, the court should consider the following factors: â€œ1) nature, extent, and difficulty of the legal services rendered; 2) time and labor devoted to the case; 3) professional standing of counsel; 4) contingency of compensation; 5) fee customarily charged in the locality for similar services; and 6) beneficial results obtained.â€Â  Blumberg v. Nealco, Inc.,  310 S.C. 492, 494, 427 S.E.2d 659, 660 (1993).Â  The court should also make specific findings of fact on the record for each of the factors.Â  Id. at 494, 427 S.E.2d at 661.Â  â€œOn appeal, absent sufficient evidentiary support on the record for each factor, the award should be reversed and the issue remanded for the trial court to make specific findings of fact.â€Â  Id.  
In this case, the trial judge considered each of the Blumberg factors, and set forth specific findings of fact on the record.Â  Sufficient evidence exists in the record to support the judgeâ€™s findings on all of the factors except for the beneficial results obtained.
In deciding the beneficial results obtained, the trial judge concluded that Purchasers were successful in securing their purchase money back and determined that the recovery was $122,000, the purchase price of the home.Â  Sellers argue this overstated the beneficial results obtained because even though Purchasers recovered the purchase price, they also had to return the home to Sellers.Â  Sellers assert that the amount of recovery was actually $122,000 less the value of the home, and argue the only evidence in the record was that the home was worth $131,000.Â  We agree.Â  
The remedy the jury chose to afford Purchasers requires them to return the home to Sellers in exchange for the purchase price of $122,000.Â  The only evidence in the record demonstrates that the home was appraised in December of 2000 for $131,000.Â  Therefore, the remedy did not provide Purchasers a recovery of $122,000, but instead placed them back in the same position they were in prior to entering the contract.Â Â Â  Thus, while we find evidence in the record to support a finding that Purchasers were successful in obtaining a rescission of their contract, we find no evidence to support reasonable attorneyâ€™s fees based on the Purchaserâ€™s contingency fee agreement with their attorney.
We hold the judge erred in awarding $40,626 in attorneyâ€™s fees, and reverse the award of fees to the extent it is based on the contingency agreement.Â Â  See Jackson v. Speed, 326 S.C. 289, 308, 486 S.E.2d 750, 759 (1997) (stating that the contract between the client and counsel does not control the determination of reasonable attorneyâ€™s fees).Â  Rather, we find an award of attorneyâ€™s fees in the amount of $26.507.06,[1] the amount submitted by Purchasersâ€™ counsel in his invoice of professional services and bolstered with his affidavit in support of attorneyâ€™s fees, to be a reasonable award of attorneyâ€™s fees. Id.Â  See also Columbia (S.C.) Teachers Federal Credit Union v. Newsome Chevrolet-Buick, 303 S.C. 162, 165-66, 399 S.E.2d 444, 447 (Ct. App. 1990) (affirming an award of attorneyâ€™s fees based upon an hourly rate even though agreement with client was contingency-based).
AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED.
GOOLSBY and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] Sellers argue on appeal that certain services rendered by paralegals and secretaries should not be included in an award of attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We find this issue is not preserved for appeal.Â  â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€Â  Wilder Corp. v. Wilke,  330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (citation omitted).Â  At the hearing, the only objection Sellers made to the invoice of Purchasersâ€™ counsel was that it was exorbitant and should be closely examined.Â  Moreover, any issues raised regarding the attorneyâ€™s fees in the Rule 59(e) motion by Sellers were never ruled upon by the trial judge.Â

title: Hansson v. Scalise Builders of South Carolina
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Tom Hansson, Appellant,
v.
Scalise Builders of South Carolina, and Sam Scalise, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Â JohnÂ  L.Â  Breeden, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-340
Heard January 13, 2005 â€“ Filed May 18, 2005

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Chalmers Carey Johnson, of Charleston, for Appellant.
Henrietta U. Golding, of Myrtle Beach, for Respondents.
      
    
  

BEATTY, J.:Â  Tom Hansson appeals the grant of summary judgment to his former supervisor and employer, Sam Scalise and Scalise Builders of South Carolina, in Hanssonâ€™s action against them for, among other things, intentional infliction of emotional distress.[1]Â  We reverse and remand.
FACTS
Employed by Scalise Builders in March 1997, Tom Hansson performed maintenance and general construction work until he resigned in February 2000.Â  During Hanssonâ€™s tenure at Scalise Builders, owned by Sam Scalise, Hansson experienced what he alleges was harassment in a hostile environment that began only five or six months after he started work.Â Â  
The environment Hansson described is one in which he was greeted daily with, â€œGood morning, fag.â€Â  Hansson also heard rumors co-workers thought he â€œwas a faggot,â€ and he was the subject of graphic comments.Â  The comments directed to Hansson included, â€œHow does it feel to have a gerbil up the ass?,â€ â€œ[Eating a banana] must come natural to you, doesnâ€™t it, Tom?,â€ and â€œIâ€™ve got your hog.Â  You want to come in the closet?â€Â  The comments were made by both Hanssonâ€™s co-workers and by Scalise himself.Â  For example, Scalise asked Hansson in front of two other co-workers if Hansson would perform oral sex upon Scalise for money.Â  
On one occasion when Hansson expressed an unwillingness to measure a kitchen, Scalise said, â€œYou donâ€™t need an attitude like that. . . . I ought to take you upstairs and f--- you myself.â€Â  In November 1999, Hansson was called into Scaliseâ€™s office.Â  Scalise said, â€œYouâ€™ve got a nice house; nice car; nice wife. . . . Youâ€™re starting to get under my skin.â€Â  The two talked and, at the end of the conversation, with a co-worker present, Scalise â€œgoosedâ€ Hansson, by sticking his finger in Hanssonâ€™s clothed anus. 
According to John Goodhart, a former supervisor of Hansson at Scalise Builders, the comments were jokesâ€”jokes of the variety Hansson admits are normal at construction sites.Â  In fact, Hansson himself joked by carrying around a dollâ€™s head in his hand and asking co-workers, â€œDo you want a little head?â€Â  Hansson admitted that he often used profanity and was not offended by such language.Â  When asked if he had ever complained to a supervisor, Hansson testified the supervisor was usually present and knew what was happening.Â  He also testified he thought telling Scalise he was offended was fruitless; he â€œ[d]idnâ€™t think it would do any goodâ€ and â€œ[j]ust figured it was the way it was.â€Â  He testified one Scalise employee, a painter working in a different area, harassed him on a weekly basis and sometimes called him names on a daily basis.Â  However, Hansson testified he did not leave his job because he liked what he was doing and â€œ99% of the time nobody botheredâ€ him.Â  
Hansson did not see a doctor or counselor for the mental anguish he claims to have suffered.Â  He did not lose time from work or experience effects on his marital relationship or ability to work.Â  However, Hansson implicitly claimed the harassment at work caused him to grit his teeth at night, for which he saw a dentist â€œonce or twice.â€Â  It also caused him to wake up repeatedly at night for about one year.Â  He resigned from Scalise Builders in March or April 2000 because of the harassment and to start his own business.Â  
After resigning, Hansson sued Scalise and Scalise Builders for intentional infliction of emotional distress, breach of contract, slander, and wrongful retention of wages.Â  Scalise and Scalise Builders filed a motion for summary judgment, which the trial court granted.Â  Hansson appealed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œThe appellate court reviews a grant of summary judgment under the same standard applied by the trial court pursuant to Rule 56, SCRCP.â€ Lanham v. Blue Cross & Blue Shield of South Carolina, 349 S.C. 356, 361, 563 S.E.2d 331, 333 (2002).Â  Granting summary judgment is proper when no genuine issue of material fact exists and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Id.Â  Where the parties dispute the conclusions to be drawn from undisputed facts, summary judgment is improper.Â  Tupper v. Dorchester County, 326 S.C. 318, 325, 487 S.E.2d 187, 191 (1997).Â  When making this determination, the court should view the evidence and all inferences that can be drawn reasonably therefrom in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Lanham, 349 S.C. at 361-62, 563 S.E.2d at 333. 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Hansson argues the trial court erred in finding no genuine issue of material fact existed as to whether the conduct in question was outrageous in his intentional infliction of emotional distress claim.Â  We agree.Â  
To recover for an intentional infliction of emotional distress claim, the plaintiff must show: 

(1) the defendant intentionally or recklessly inflicted severe emotional distress or was certain or substantially certain that such distress would result from his conduct . . .; (2) the conduct was so â€œextreme and outrageousâ€ as to exceed â€œall possible bounds of decencyâ€ and must be regarded as â€˜atrocious, and utterly intolerable in a civilized communityâ€™ . . .; (3) the actions of the defendant caused the plaintiffâ€™s emotional distress; and (4) the emotional distress suffered by the plaintiff was â€œsevereâ€ so that â€œno reasonable man could be expected to endure it.â€

Folkens v. Hunt, 290 S.C. 194, 203, 348 S.E.2d 839, 844 (Ct. App. 1986) (quoting Ford v. Hutson, 276 S.C. 157, 162, 276 S.E.2d 776, 778 (1981)). 
In reviewing whether summary judgment is appropriate regarding a claim for intentional infliction of emotional distress, the trial court must first determine whether the â€œdefendantâ€™s conduct may be reasonably regarded as so extreme and outrageous as to allow recovery.â€Â  Butts v. AVX Corp., 292 S.C. 256, 262-63, 355 S.E.2d 876, 880 (Ct. App. 1987); Folkens, 290 S.C. at 203, 348 S.E.2d at 844-45.Â  Once the initial showing is made that the conduct could be reasonably considered extreme and outrageous, the matter should be submitted to a jury to determine whether the conduct was â€œsufficiently extreme and outrageous to result in liability.â€Â  Fleming v. Rose, 338 S.C. 524, 537, 526 S.E.2d 732, 739 (Ct. App. 2000), revâ€™d on other grounds, 350 S.C. 488, 567 S.E.2d 857 (2002).Â  â€œ[T]he judge should submit the issue to the jury only where reasonable persons might differ on the issue.â€Â  Gattison v. South Carolina State College, 318 S.C. 148, 151-52, 456 S.E2d 414, 416 (Ct. App. 1995); see Ford, 276 S.C. at 166, 276 S.E.2d at 780 (explaining â€œit is the province of the jury to make a factual determinationâ€).Â  One instance in which the matter should be submitted to the jury is when the business relationship may make the conduct excusable.Â  Ford, 276 S.C. at 166, 276 S.E.2d at 780 (noting â€œa business relationship may sometimes justify oneâ€™s conduct and make that conduct excusable or at least less culpable, but it is at most a factor to be considered and weighed by the juryâ€).
To be outrageous, the conduct generally must include â€œâ€˜hostile or abusive encountersâ€™ or â€˜coercive or oppressive conduct.â€™â€Â  Fleming, 338 S.C. at 538, 526 S.E.2d at 739 (citations omitted); see Gattison, 318 S.C. at 152, 456 S.E.2d at 416 (noting â€œthat mere retaliatory discharge . . . absent claims of verbal assaults or hostile, abusive encounters, did not rise to the level required for the tort of outrageâ€); Wright v. Sparrow, 298 S.C. 469, 473, 381 S.E.2d 503, 506 (Ct. App. 1989) (finding the conduct was not so extreme and outrageous as to exceed all possible bounds of decency without evidence of â€œhostile or abusive encounters or oppressive abuseâ€).Â  A single encounter of verbal abuse may be insufficient to prevent summary judgment.Â  See Shipman v. Glenn, 314 S.C. 327, 329, 443 S.E.2d 921, 923 (Ct. App. 1994) (affirming the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment in a case involving a single incident in which the employer ridiculed an employeeâ€™s speech impediment and threatened to terminate the individualâ€™s employment).Â  However, evidence of repeated verbal abuse may present sufficient evidence of outrageous conduct.Â  See Ford, 276 S.C. at 166, 267 S.E.2d at 780 (holding evidence of repeated incidents of vicious, cruel, profane, oral accosting was susceptible to the inference it was â€œnot a mere complaint . . . but was instead a continuing pattern of highly questionable conduct over a period of almost two years,â€ and thus sufficient to support the jury verdict).
Here, the trial court found Hansson did not experience â€œhostile or abusive encountersâ€ or â€œcoercive or oppressive conduct.â€Â  Relying on Hanssonâ€™s deposition testimony that he was happy at his job because he was left alone 99% of the time, the court determined that the conduct was not so extreme and outrageous as to meet the second element of an intentional infliction of emotional distress claim.Â  
Viewed in a light most favorable to Hansson, the evidence, at the very least, is conflicting and susceptible to more than one reasonable inference. The conduct of Scalise and Scalise Builders included constant commentary about Hanssonâ€™s sexuality, repeated profanity directed towards Hansson, and even lewd physical contact.Â  These abusive encounters were not limited to a single incident and Hansson indicated he suffered from emotional distress, including sleeplessness and teeth grinding, as a result.Â  Although the evidence conflicts as to the frequency of the harassment, it does suggest repeated occurrences.Â  The evidence also conflicts as to whether the comments were made in a joking manner as opposed to a hostile one.Â  Furthermore, the fact that the behavior of the defendants occurred on construction sites and the fact that Hansson himself used profanity and made off-color jokes may serve to make the conduct excusable.Â  However, such a decision is for a jury to make.Â  Because reasonable minds could differ on whether the conduct of Scalise and Scalise Builders was outrageous, the trial court erred in failing to submit the matter to the jury. 
CONCLUSION
Hansson sufficiently established that reasonable minds could differ as to whether the conduct of Scalise and Scalise Builders was outrageous.Â  Because he demonstrated a genuine issue of material fact regarding outrageousness, summary judgment was not appropriate.Â  Thus, the decision of the trial court is
REVERSED AND REMANDED.
 HUFF, JJ., concurs.
 KITTREDGE, JJ., dissents in a separate opinion.
 KITTREDGE, J.: Â I respectfully dissent.
While I agree with the majorityâ€™s conclusion that â€œreasonable minds could differ as to whether the conduct of Scalise and Scalise Builders was outrageous,â€ I find Hansson failed to show any facts legally sufficient for a jury to conclude he actually suffered severe emotional distress as a result of the alleged conduct.Â  I would therefore affirm the circuit courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment in favor of Respondents Sam Scalise and Scalise Builders. 
As set out by the majority, our supreme court has adopted a rule of liability relating to intentional infliction of emotional distress that requires a plaintiff to prove four distinct elements. See Ford v. Hutson, 276 S.C. 157, 162, 276 S.E.2d 776, 778 (1981) (our supreme courtâ€™s first articulation of the four element test for establishing intentional infliction of emotional distress).Â  I would concur in the majorityâ€™s finding that a proper jury question is raised as to the first three of these four elements regarding (1) the intentional or reckless nature of the alleged conduct, (2) the degree to which the alleged conduct is sufficiently â€œextreme and outrageous,â€ and (3) the potential causal connection to the claimed â€œdistress.â€Â  However, I part company with the majority on the question raised by the fourth element: whether â€œthe emotional distress suffered by the plaintiff was â€˜severeâ€™ so that â€˜no reasonable man could be expected to endure it.â€™â€ Id. (quoting Restatement (Second) of Torts Â§ 46 cmt. j (1965)).Â  
In articulating the fourth element of the tort in this manner, our supreme court has clearly indicated that, to satisfy this element, more must be shown than mere â€œemotional distress.â€Â  Rather, the standard expressed in the rule requires a plaintiff to show he suffered a severely disabling emotional response to the defendantâ€™s conduct.Â  Comment â€œjâ€ of section 46 of the Restatement (Second) of Tortsâ€”upon which our supreme court relied heavily in adopting this rule of liability[2]â€”elaborates on this requirement:
Emotional distress passes under various names, such as mental suffering, mental anguish, mental or nervous shock, or the like. It includes all highly unpleasant mental reactions, such as fright, horror, grief, shame, humiliation, embarrassment, anger, chagrin, disappointment, worry, and nausea.Â  It is only where it is extreme that the liability arises.Â  Complete emotional tranquillity is seldom attainable in this world, and some degree of transient and trivial emotional distress is a part of the price of living among people.Â  The law intervenes only where the distress inflicted is so severe that no reasonable man could be expected to endure it.Â  The intensity and the duration of the distress are factors to be considered in determining its severity.Â  Severe distress must be proved; but in many cases the extreme and outrageous character of the defendantâ€™s conduct is in itself important evidence that the distress has existed. 
. . . .
It is for the court to determine whether on the evidence severe emotional distress can be found; it is for the jury to determine whether, on the evidence, it has in fact existed.
Restatement (Second) of Torts Â§ 46 cmt. j (1965) (emphasis added); see also Rhodes v. Security Fin. Corp. of Landrum, 268 S.C. 300, 233 S.E.2d 105 (1977) (holding that there is no liability for emotional distress without a showing that the distress inflicted was extreme or severe and where there is no showing that plaintiffâ€™s emotional upset was other than transient and trivial).[3]Â  Therefore, the severity of emotional distress not only bears on the amount of recovery, but in the first instance â€œ[i]t is for the court to determine whether on the evidence severe emotional distress can be found.â€ Restatement, supra.
The burden upon plaintiffs to show more than minorâ€”or even moderateâ€”emotional distress as a prerequisite to any liability is in keeping with the rigorous analysis our courts have applied to claims of intentional infliction of emotional distress.Â  Indeed, we have noted that claims arising under this tort should be scrutinized closely by the trial and appellate courts so that this cause of action is not allowed to become a â€œpanacea for wounded feelings rather than reprehensible conduct.â€ Todd v. South Carolina Farm Bureau Mut. Ins. Co., 283 S.C. 155, 171, 321 S.E.2d 602, 611 (Ct. App. 1984), revâ€™d on other grounds, 287 S.C. 190, 336 S.E.2d 472 (1985); see also Gattison v. S.C. State College, 318 S.C. 148, 152, 456 S.E.2d 414, 416 (Ct. App. 1995) (comprehensively surveying the decisional authority in our state addressing claims of intentional infliction of emotional distress and reiterating â€œour reluctance to permit the tort of outrage to become a â€˜panacea for wounded feelings rather than reprehensible conductâ€™â€).Â  The particularized and exacting legal standard that applies to claims of intentional infliction of emotional distress thus imposes upon our trial courts a critical gatekeeping role to ensure this tort does not become a broad â€œcatchallâ€ that is raised when other tort remedies fail.
Examining the claim in the present case, I would hold the circuit court correctly ruled there is no evidence, legally sufficient for submission to the jury, that the distress allegedly suffered by Hansson was â€œsevereâ€ within the contemplation of the rule.Â  Hansson conceded that â€œninety-nine percent (99%) of the time, no one [at the worksite] bothered [him].â€Â Â  Indeed, he admitted he was a willing participant in some of the alleged offensive exchanges.Â  Hansson testified that he, too, â€œjoked aroundâ€ and frequently used profanity at the construction siteâ€”even walking around the worksite with the head of a doll in his hand, holding his hand out to co-workers and asking, â€œdo you want a little head?â€Â  Hansson in fact admitted in his deposition testimony that one of the targets of his â€œdollâ€™s headâ€ joke was Sam Scalise, the very individual Hansson alleges was the source of much of the harassment he claims to have suffered.Â  On the other hand, the â€œmental anguishâ€ Hansson claims to have endured as a result of Respondentsâ€™ conduct was unaccompanied by any evidentiary particulars other than vague assertions that he lost sleep and that his dentist told him he appeared to be grinding his teeth at night.Â  There is no evidence that Hansson ever sought treatment from a physician or any other health care provider or counselor as a result of his emotional distress.Â  There is also no evidence that the alleged conduct impaired Hanssonâ€™s ability to perform his work. To the contrary, Hansson specifically testified the alleged harassment did not affect his ability to do his job. 
Granting the vulgar and inappropriate nature of Respondentsâ€™ alleged conduct towards Hansson, I nevertheless would find that, as a matter of law, this record fails to establish the fourth element of the cause of actionâ€”that the emotional distress suffered by the plaintiff was so severe that no reasonable man could be expected to endure it.Â  I would therefore affirm the circuit courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment on this issue.

[1]Â  In addition to his action for intentional infliction of emotional distress, Hanssonâ€™s complaint alleged causes of action for breach of contract, slander, and wrongful retention of wages.Â  Although the trial court granted summary judgment on all the claims, Hanssonâ€™s only issue on appeal is whether the trial court erred in granting summary judgment on the claim of intentional infliction of emotional distress.Â  
[2] See Ford, 276 S.C. at 162, 276 S.E.2d at 778-79 (quoting extensively from the comments to this Restatement section).
[3] Though Rhodes v. Security Finance Corp. of Landrum was decided before the express recognition of the tort of intentional infliction of emotional distress in Ford v. Hutson, it was cited with approval by the supreme court in that case.Â  See Ford, 276 S.C. at 161, 276 S.E.2d at 778.

title: Fassuliotis v. Fassuliotis
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Dennis Fassuliotis, Appellant,
v.
Maureen Fassuliotis, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Paul W. Garfinkel, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-341
Submitted April 1, 2005 â€“ Filed May 18, 2005

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART
AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Cynthia Barrier Castengera, of Newland, N.C., for Appellant.
Robert Rosen, of Charleston and Sabrina R. Grogan, of Mt. Pleasant, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this domestic relations action, Dennis Fassuliotis (Father) sought modification of his visitation rights.Â  Father appeals from the family courtâ€™s order granting Maureen Fassuliotisâ€™ (Mother) motion to dismiss his complaint.Â  Additionally, Father challenges the award of $2,800.00 in attorneyâ€™s fees to Mother.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand. 
FACTS
The parties were divorced in 2001 and have two children, ages eight and nine.Â  During the divorce litigation, the parties executed a detailed â€œStipulation Regarding Custody and Visitation.â€Â  This agreement was incorporated into the final divorce decree.[1]Â  
Pursuant to the terms of the custody and visitation agreement, the parties have joint custody of the children, with Mother having primary physical custody.Â  Accordingly, the children reside with Mother, but have visitation with Father every other weekend, every Wednesday afternoon, and Monday afternoons following weekends when they are with Mother.Â  Detailed stipulations control holiday and summer visitations.Â  The parties also agreed that they would be entitled to additional visitation at such other times as they may agree in writing.Â  
The parties further agreed that Wife must consult with Husband before making changes in the childrenâ€™s schooling and extracurricular activities.Â  Additionally, the children are to be raised in the Greek Orthodox faith, and Father is responsible for their religious training.Â  Father is to consult with Mother regarding any changes in their training.Â  He is entitled to enroll them in Sunday school and summer Bible school for a minimum of one week per summer, provided he pays the cost and it does not conflict with their academic summer school.Â  
In 2002, Father commenced an action for modification of visitation and at the same time filed a motion for emergency relief requesting the family court to order Mother to trade visitation weekends with him so he could take the children to a family gathering in Connecticut.Â  The family court granted Father the emergency relief requested.Â  
In his complaint for modification of visitation, Father alleges Mother has engaged in actions that were detrimental to the best interests of the children.Â  Specifically, Father alleges the Mother: (1) keeps the children in daycare even though Father is available to care for them; (2) refuses to allow him to take the children to Greek Orthodox services on Sunday mornings during weekends when the children are with her; (3) refuses to allow him to take the children to Greek school on Monday afternoons when Mother has the children; (4) has refused to allow Father to take the children to family gatherings occurring during her visitation times; and (5) unilaterally removed the children from Montessori school and put them in a public school, which dismisses earlier, but refuses to allow Father to pick them up from school on his visitation days.Â  
Father prayed the family court grant him the right of first refusal to care for the children when Mother is at work rather than putting them in daycare or leaving them with babysitters.Â  Father also requested the court require Mother to give him the option of taking the children to church on Sundays and Monday afternoons when they are with her unless she notifies him within 48 hours of the event that she has alternate plans for them.Â  Additionally, Father asked the court to require Mother to allow him visitation for family gatherings so long as he offers Mother reasonable exchange options.Â  He also demanded that Mother allow him to pick up the children from school when school dismisses before the scheduled 2:30 p.m. transfer time, and that she allow him to keep the children on the day following Monday and Wednesday visitations if public school is not in session unless Mother takes the day off from work and cares for the children herself.Â  Finally, Father sought court-ordered mediation to resolve visitation disputes without going back to court, appointment of a guardian ad litem, and attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  
Mother filed a motion to dismiss Fatherâ€™s complaint for failure to state a claim under Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP.Â  After a hearing, the family court granted Motherâ€™s motion, finding that Father had failed to allege facts from which the court could find a material and substantial change affecting the welfare of the children.[2]Â  The family court also awarded Mother $2,800.00 in attorneyâ€™s fees for defending the action.Â  
Father, acting pro se, filed a motion to amend the judgment, or alternatively, for a new trial.[3]Â  Fatherâ€™s motion challenged the order of dismissal on several grounds.Â  In relevant part, Father argued that the order violates Rules 20 and 26, SCRFC, in that the award of attorneyâ€™s fees was determined based upon financial declarations from the prior divorce action.Â  Father also contended that the family court failed to consider the factors required by law in determining the amount of the award and that the amount was excessive.Â  The family court denied the motion, but more fully set forth the basis for its award of attorney fees.Â  
This appeal followed.Â  Father raises two issues on appeal:Â  (1) the family court erred in dismissing his action; and (2) the family court erred in awarding Mother attorneyâ€™s fees and costs. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Rule 2(a), SCRFC, provides that the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure apply when no Family Court Rule applies.Â  Under Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP, a motion to dismiss may be granted when a defendant demonstrates that the plaintiff has failed to plead facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action.Â  Flateau v. Harrelson, 355 S.C. 197, 201, 584 S.E.2d 413, 415 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  The family courtâ€™s ruling must be based solely on the allegations on the face of the complaint.Â  Id. at 201-02, 584 S.E.2d at 415.Â  The motion should be denied if facts alleged and inferences therefrom would entitle the plaintiff to relief on any theory of the case.Â  Baird v. Charleston County, 333 S.C. 519, 527, 511 S.E.2d 69, 73 (1999).Â  An appellate court applies the same standard of review as the trial court.Â  Williams v. Condon, 347 S.C. 227, 233, 553 S.E.2d 496, 500 (Ct. App. 2001). 
LAW/ANALYSIS
A.Â Â Â Â Â  Motion to Dismiss
Father first argues that the complaint alleges sufficient facts to survive Motherâ€™s motion to dismiss.Â  We agree in part.
A judicial order fixing visitation rights is not final, and may be modified based on changed circumstances.Â  McGregor v. McGregor, 255 S.C. 179, 183, 177 S.E.2d 599, 600-01 (1970).Â  When a court has previously established visitation, the moving party has the burden of showing a change of circumstances sufficient to warrant a change in visitation rights.Â  Ingold v. Ingold, 304 S.C. 316, 320, 404 S.E.2d 35, 37 (Ct. App. 1991).Â  
In the case sub judice, the parties agreed to detailed visitation.Â  While Father argues in his brief that the standard for modification of visitation should be lower than the standard for a change in custody, we can find no such distinction in the law.Â  The guiding standard for both situations is a change in circumstances.Â  See Ingold, 304 S.C. at 320, 404 S.E.2d at 37 (applying the standard to visitation); Kisling v. Allison, 343 S.C. 674, 678-79, 541 S.E.2d 273, 275-76 (Ct. App. 2001) (applying the standard to custody); see also 24A Am. Jur. 2d Divorce and Separation Â§ 991 (2004) (providing the same standard for modification of both custody and visitation without comment).Â  
There are no hard and fast rules for determining when a sufficient change in circumstances has occurred to warrant modification of visitation.Â  Kisling, 343 S.C. at 679, 541 S.E.2d at 275.Â  When the non-custodial parent seeks modification in custody, two criteria must be established:Â  (1) there must have been a substantial change in circumstances affecting the welfare of the children; and (2) the proposed modification is in the overall best interests of the children.Â  Latimer v. Farmer, 360 S.C. 375, 381, 602 S.E.2d 32, 35 (2004).Â  The change in circumstances must occur after the date of the original order setting custody and visitation.Â  Kisling, 343 S.C. at 679, 541 S.E.2d at 276.Â  
On a motion to dismiss, we must ordinarily consider only the allegations on the face of the complaint.Â  Flateau v. Harrelson, 355 S.C. 197, 201-02, 584 S.E.2d 413, 415 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  â€œThe question to be considered is whether, in the light most favorable to the plaintiff, the pleadings articulate any valid claim for relief.â€Â  Williams v. Condon, 347 S.C. 227, 233, 553 S.E.2d 496, 499 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  However, as noted above, the parties have, in effect, made the divorce decree and custody and visitation agreement a part of the pleadings.
Father asserts in his brief that at the time of the divorce he could not have foreseen that Mother would place the children in daycare or with a babysitter when they were with her.Â  He therefore requests the â€œright of first refusalâ€ to care for the children when they would otherwise be with a babysitter or in daycare. Â These allegations do not assert a change of conditions.Â  The pleadings reflect that Father knew Mother worked at the time of the divorce and would likely be required to work after the divorce to provide for herself and the children.Â  If he wanted to ensure that the children were not placed in daycare, he could have negotiated that in the settlement.Â  Furthermore, Father cites no law in support of his demand for a court-ordered right of first refusal.
The complaint seeks â€œat least two hours of mediationâ€ to resolve minor visitation issues generally.Â  Father alleges that Mother â€œunilaterally changed the childrenâ€™s school,â€ and that, unlike private school, the public school sometimes dismisses before 2:30 p.m., but Mother refuses to allow him to pick the children up from school when it dismisses.Â  The agreement specifically provides that Mother was not required to keep the children in private school, but she was to consult with Father on any changes in schooling or extracurricular activities. The agreement also provides that her failure to do so gave Father the right to require â€œone mediation session on the issue.â€Â  The Fatherâ€™s complaint claims the Mother â€œunilaterallyâ€ changed the childrenâ€™s school, thus, inferentially creating the circumstance requiring the children to go to daycare after school.Â  We hold that these allegations are sufficient to permit the family court to find husband entitled to mediation on this issue.Â  We remand this issue to the family court.Â  Further, we caution the parties that parents awarded joint custody have a duty to act in the childrenâ€™s best interests, and may not use them as pawns or clubs in their battles with each other.Â  Nash v. Byrd, 298 S.C. 530, 536, 381 S.E.2d 913, 916 (Ct. App. 1989).Â  
Father also asserts that because the decree makes him primarily responsible for the childrenâ€™s religious upbringing, he should be allowed to take the children to church during Motherâ€™s visitation periods.Â  The agreement also states that Father is to consult with Mother on changes in religious training, and that he is entitled to enroll them in Sunday School.Â  While this language does not require the Mother to take them to church or Sunday school, it certainly infers that the Mother will cooperate with the Father in their religious training.Â  Moreover, it can be inferred from such language that the parties thought regular attendance at Sunday school and church was essential to the childrenâ€™s religious training.Â  Construing the pleadings in the light most favorable to the Father, and giving him the benefit of reasonable inferences, we hold they set forth facts upon which a court could grant relief to the Father. 
Finally, Father seeks a modification of the agreement that would require Mother to allow him to have the children for visiting relatives and family gatherings.Â  The parties have already agreed to a detailed visitation schedule.Â  When Father sought emergency relief to take the children to an important family gathering on one of Motherâ€™s weekends, the relief was granted.Â  Therefore, Father alleges no circumstance now existing to warrant such a modification.Â  Thus, there was no error in the trial courtâ€™s dismissal of this claim. 
B.Â Â Â Â Â  Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Father also challenges the award of attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  He argues the following on appeal: (1) the family court failed to make adequate findings of fact pursuant to Rule 26 and, more specifically, failed to require financial declarations pursuant to Rule 20 before making the award; (2) the family court failed to consider the factors required by law; and (3) Father was improperly denied his request to question Motherâ€™s counsel regarding hours spent in preparation.Â  An attorney fee award must be based on adequate findings of fact.Â  Clearly, the order of dismissal that awarded the Mother attorney fees included no findings of fact.Â  Nevertheless, the court made findings in its order on reconsideration.Â  However, in view of our decision to reverse and remand certain issues, we also reverse and remand the matter of attorney fees.
CONCLUSION
We hold that the family court improperly dismissed Fatherâ€™s complaint for failure to state a cause of action as to his claims regarding the religious training of the children and the mediation of visitation issues regarding picking the children up from school prior to 2:30 p.m. on Fatherâ€™s visitation days.Â  We further hold that in light of this decision, the award of attorneyâ€™s fees should be reversed and remanded to the family court.Â  Based on the foregoing, the order of the family court is hereby 
 AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED.
BEATTY, SHORT, JJ., and CURETON, AJ., concur

[1] At the hearing on the motion to dismiss, Motherâ€™s attorney handed up to the court a copy of the divorce decree and the agreement regarding custody and visitation.Â  Fatherâ€™s attorney did not object.Â  Moreover, the trial judge indicated he would read the documents and consider them in his decision.Â  The effect of this is to incorporate these documents into the pleadings for Rule 12(b)(6) purposes. 
[2] We note that the order of dismissal grants the Father â€œleave to file another complaint with this court if he believes in good faith that he can state facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action.â€ 
[3] The order notes that Father alleged no procedural basis for his motion.Â  However, the motion clearly states it is based on Rules 59 and 60, SCRCP.Â  See Richland County v. Kaiser, 351 S.C. 89, 94, 567 S.E.2d 260, 262 (Ct. App. 2002) (holding that it is the substance of the relief sought that matters regardless of its form).Â  Moreover, at the motion hearing, both parties referred to Fatherâ€™s motion as one for â€œreconsideration.â€

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA

v.
Benjamin K. Cantrell, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Henry F. Floyd, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2005-UP-345
Submitted May 1, 2005 â€“ Filed May 18, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Benjamin K. Cantrell, of Greer, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Mark Rapoport, Office of the Attorney General, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  After Benjamin K. Cantrell was convicted and sentenced for driving under the influence in magistrateâ€™s court, he appealed to the circuit court.Â  The circuit court dismissed the appeal as untimely.Â  Cantrell now appeals the order of the circuit court.Â  We affirm.1
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On June 10, 2002, a jury found Cantrell guilty of driving under the influence, and Judge Harold Grimsley sentenced Cantrell to a fine of $737.00.Â  On June 24, 2002, Cantrell sent his notice of appeal via facsimile to Magistrate Cagleâ€™s office.Â  The July 30, 2002 return of the magistrate noted the appeal was not filed in a timely manner, and summarily addressed Cantrellâ€™s reasons for appeal. Â Following a hearing on April 14, 2003, the circuit court found the appeal was not filed within ten days after sentence pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 18-3-30 and, thus, the appeal was untimely.Â  The circuit court therefore dismissed the appeal.Â  This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Cantrell argues the circuit court improperly dismissed his appeal as untimely.Â  He asserts his notice of appeal was delayed because he thought he had thirty days to appeal based on the rule for civil appeals and the fact his case was assigned a civil case number.Â  
Initially, we question whether this issue is preserved for our review as this argument appears to be raised for the first time before this court.2Â  In the hearing before the circuit court, the solicitor argued the appeal was not filed within ten days as required by statute.Â  When the court asked Cantrell what he had to say in that regard, Cantrell stated, â€œNot a whole lot, Your Honor.â€Â  The court then asked Cantrell if he agreed that he filed the appeal after ten days and Cantrell replied, â€œProbably so.â€Â  The court concluded it was a jurisdictional issue and dismissed the appeal.Â  Cantrell never argued to the circuit court that he was misled into believing he had thirty days to file the appeal based on the case number assigned to the matter.3Â  See South Carolina Wildlife & Marine Res. Depâ€™t v. Kunkle, 287 S.C. 177, 179 n.2, 336 S.E.2d 468, 469 n.2 (1985) (noting a reviewing court may not rule on issues not raised in the lower court).Â Â  
At any rate, we find Cantrellâ€™s argument has no merit.Â  â€œEvery person convicted before a magistrate of any offense whatever and sentenced may appeal from the sentence to the Court of Common Pleas for the county.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 18-3-10 (Supp. 2004).Â  â€œThe appellant shall, within ten days after sentence, serve notice of appeal upon the magistrate who tried the case, stating the grounds upon which the appeal is founded.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 18-3-30 (1985).Â  Failure to comply with the procedural requirements for an appeal divests the court of appellate jurisdiction.Â  State v. Brown, 358 S.C. 382, 387, 596 S.E.2d 39, 41 (2004). 
Irrespective of Cantrellâ€™s belief that he had thirty days to appeal based on the number assigned to his case, Cantrellâ€™s case was clearly an appeal from a criminal conviction and sentence in magistrateâ€™s court.Â  Cantrellâ€™s notice of appeal was not served within ten days of his sentence as required by statute.4Â  Because the appeal was untimely, the circuit court did not have jurisdiction to hear the appeal and properly dismissed it.5Â  Accordingly, the order of the circuit court is
 AFFIRMED.
