  PER CURIAM:Â  Teresa Utsey Crosby appeals from the family courtâ€™s decision to terminate her parental rights to Tayizah Utsey on the grounds that she neglected the child and it is not reasonably likely the home could be made safe in twelve months.Â  We affirm. 
  FACTS
    

The South Carolina Department of Social Services (DSS) first became involved with Crosby in 1994, when DSS initiated a removal action against her.Â  The action concerned seven minor children in Crosbyâ€™s custody. Â Three of the seven children were subsequently placed in the custody of their grandmother, and the remaining four remained in DSS custody.Â  Crosby failed to remedy the conditions that required removal and a court terminated her parental rights as to the four children in DSS custody.
This child was born July 16, 2002, and lived with 
Crosby until her incarceration in December 2003.Â  Crosby left the child in the custody of two of her grown children, Charles and Takita.Â  On January 9, 2004, Takita brought the child to the hospital because the child suffered a severe respiratory infection.Â  Takita was arrested on the same day.Â  At the hospital, DSS learned of Crosbyâ€™s incarceration.Â  Because no family members were located to take custody of the child, DSS placed him into protective custody.
DSS brought a removal action and sought to terminate Crosbyâ€™s parental rights.Â  The complaint alleged a pattern of neglect on the part of Crosby and asserted the situation requiring removal was not reasonably likely to be remedied within twelve months.Â  
At trial, the foster mother testified that the child was underweight when DSS placed him in her custody.Â  In addition, he could not chew or swallow solid foods, despite having a full set of teeth. Â Also, the childâ€™s immunizations were not up to date.Â  Finally, she testified: â€œHe did not make any motions, no talking, no babbling . . . he was basically a shell of a child when we received him which caused us great concern.â€Â  
A DSS caseworker recounted the history of Crosbyâ€™s involvement with DSS.Â  She stated Crosby never successfully completed a treatment plan.Â  The caseworker testified:Â  â€œThis child has a great many medical problems and heâ€™s in the best care where he needs to be at this point in time.â€Â  Ultimately, she testified that given the condition of the child when he entered the custody of DSS, it was neglect for Crosby to leave the child with her other children.Â 
Crosby testified her children were willing to and capable of taking care of the child.Â  Crosbyâ€™s children, however, were not present at the trial to demonstrate their willingness to accept custody.
The trial court found â€œ[t]he medical condition of the minor child when he entered foster care, coupled with the fact that the minor child had no one to take care of him or ensure his needs were being met at the time he was taken into emergency protective custody, constitutes neglect by Teresa Crosby.â€Â  The court further found that Crosbyâ€™s history with DSS, along with the findings of physical neglect of the child, constituted a repetition of neglect that made it unlikely the home could be made safe within twelve months.Â  The court terminated her parental rights pursuant to section 20-7-1572(1) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2004). 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Crosby contends the trial court erred in terminating her parental rights under section 20-7-1572(1) because there was no evidence she neglected the child by leaving him in the custody of her grown children.Â  We disagree.
Section 20-7-1572 states:

  The family court may order the termination of parental rights upon a finding of one or more of the following grounds and a finding that termination is in the best interest of the child: 
  1) The child or another child in the home has been harmed as defined in Section 20-7-490, and because of the severity or repetition of the abuse or neglect, it is not reasonably likely that the home can be made safe within twelve months.Â  In determining the likelihood that the home can be made safe, the parentâ€™s previous abuse or neglect of the child or another child in the home may be considered. 

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(1) (Supp. 2004).Â  Section 20-7-490 states in pertinent part as follows:Â 

  (2) â€œChild abuse or neglectâ€, or â€œharmâ€ occurs when the parent, guardian, or other person responsible for the childâ€™s welfare:
  (a)    inflicts or allows to be inflicted upon the child physical or mental injury or engages in acts or omissions which present a substantial risk of physical or mental injury to the child . . .; 
  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . . . 
  (c) fails to supply the child with adequate food, clothing, shelter, or education as required under Article 1 of Chapter 65 of Title 59, supervision appropriate to the childâ€™s age and development, or health care though financially able to do so or offered financial or other reasonable means to do so and the failure to do so has caused or presents a substantial risk of causing physical or mental injury. . . ;
  (d) abandons the child;
  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â . . . .
  (f) has committed abuse or neglect as described in subsections (a) through (e) such that a child who subsequently becomes part of the personâ€™s household is at substantial risk of one of those forms of abuse or neglect.

Id.
As found by the trial court, Crosby has a â€œlong history of neglect.â€Â  The prior action, coupled with the poor medical and developmental condition of the child in this action, support the courtâ€™s finding that Crosby neglected the child.Â  The repetition of neglect likely would not be remedied within twelve months, as Crosby remains incarcerated and no person has indicated a willingness to accept custody of the child.Â  Accordingly, there is ample evidence in the record to support the trial courtâ€™s finding that Crosbyâ€™s parental rights should be terminated under section 20-7-1572(1).
AFFIRMED.[1]
GOOLSBY, HUFF, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

PER CURIAM:Â  In this landlord/tenant action, Helen L. Fleshman, in her capacity as personal representative to the estate of her late husband, James G. Fleshman, appeals a circuit courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment in favor of Trilogy and CarOrder.com (collectively Respondents).Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTS

James G. Fleshman owned commercial property in Richland County. Â On August 15, 1999, he entered into a three-year lease with CarOrder.com, which was scheduled to end on August 14, 2002.Â  Respondent Trilogy guaranteed CarOrder.comâ€™s performance.Â  The lease provided a renewal option for three successive two-year periods.Â  The lease also provided that CarOrder.com could sublease the premises with Fleshmanâ€™s written approval.Â  
With Fleshmanâ€™s consent, CarOrder.com entered into a sublease with a company known as Bentleyâ€™s for a term beginning on September 1, 2000 and ending on August 14, 2002.Â  Bentleyâ€™s agreed to pay rent and to maintain the premises as required under the master lease between Fleshman and CarOrder.com.Â  Fleshman approved the agreement in writing by signing the sublease.Â  In May 2001, Dance America, LLC (Dance America) purchased Bentleyâ€™s assets and was assigned the sublease.Â  
On June 6, 2002, CarOrder.com provided written notice to Fleshman that it would not exercise its option to renew the master lease and that both leases would terminate on August 14, 2002.Â  On August 8, 2002, Dance America wrote a letter to Fleshman, seeking to exercise the renewal option.Â  Fleshman then wrote a letter to Trilogy dated August 14, 2002, in which he expressed his lack of interest in extending the lease and requested that Trilogy remove Dance America from the premises.Â  Respondents replied on August 28, 2002, explaining that because they no longer had a legal interest in the property, they had no right or duty to remove Dance America from the premises.Â  
Ultimately, Fleshman successfully brought an ejectment proceeding against Dance America.Â  Fleshman also brought an action against Respondents, arguing they had an obligation to remove Dance America.[1]Â  Fleshman asserted he was entitled to collect, inter alia, costs for the ejectment action, compensation for loss of economic advantage, and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  
Respondents filed a motion to dismiss the complaint for failure to state a claim under Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP.Â  Fleshman amended the complaint twice, and the parties agreed the motion to dismiss would apply to both amended complaints.Â  The trial court granted the motion and denied Fleshmanâ€™s subsequent motion to reconsider.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW

â€œIn deciding whether the trial court properly granted the motion to dismiss, this Court must consider whether the complaint, viewed in the light most favorable to the plaintiff, states any valid claim for relief.â€Â  Flateau v. Harrelson, 355 S.C. 197, 202, 584 S.E.2d 413, 415 (Ct. App. 2003) (citing Gentry v. Yonce, 337 S.C. 1, 5, 522 S.E.2d 137, 139 (1999) and Cowart v. Poore, 337 S.C. 359, 523 S.E.2d 182 (Ct. App. 1999)).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS 

I.Â  Motion to Dismiss
Fleshman argues the trial court erred in granting the motion to dismiss because Respondents assumed the role of landlord when they sublet the property.Â  We disagree.
When a defendant demonstrates that a plaintiff has failed to state facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action, the trial court may dismiss the claim.Â  The Hous. Auth. of City of Columbia v. Cornerstone Hous., LLC, 356 S.C. 328, 333-34, 588 S.E.2d 617, 620 (Ct. App. 2003) (citations omitted).Â  A dismissal pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP, is appropriate when the factual allegations in the complaint, even if assumed to be true, fail to state a cause of action.Â  Chewning v. Ford Motor Co., 346 S.C. 28, 32-33, 550 S.E.2d 584, 586 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  
Section 27-35-60 of the South Carolina Code (1991), defines the relationship and correspondent duties between a landlord, tenant, and sublessee as follows:

  A sublease by a tenant without written consent of the landlord is a nullity insofar as the rights of the landlord are concerned, except that rent collected by a tenant from a subtenant shall be deemed to be held in trust by the tenant for the benefit of the landlord until the payment of the landlordâ€™s claim for rent. But when the premises have been sublet the sublessor, as between himself and the subtenant or sublessee, shall be deemed the landlord and the sublessee the tenant under him and the provisions of Chapters 33 through 37, Â§ 27-39-10 and Article 3 of Chapter 39 of this Title, other than Â§Â§ 27-35-80, 27-35-170 and 27-35-180, 27-39-280 and 27-39-300 shall apply to sublessors and sublessees, as between themselves, as in other cases of landlord and tenant.

Significantly, statutes governing ejectment proceedings apply only when a landlord and tenant relationship actually exists.Â  See, e.g., Stewart-Jones Co. v. Shehan, 127 S.C. 451, 456, 121 S.E. 374, 376 (1924); see also S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 27-37-20 (1991) (providing an ejectment action is instituted by a magistrate-issued rule upon application of the landlord).Â  The term â€œlandlordâ€ includes â€œthe owner or person in possession or entitled to possession of the real estate used or occupied by the tenant.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 27-33-10(7) (1991).
When interpreting a contract that is clear and unambiguous, the court must construe its provisions according to the terms used by the parties, understood in their plain, ordinary, and popular sense.Â  Schulmeyer v. State Farm Fire & Cas. Co., 353 S.C. 491, 495, 579 S.E.2d 132, 134 (2003)Â  (citations omitted).Â  â€œThe Court cannot write a contract for the parties. When the parties have not, expressly or by implication, agreed upon essential terms of a contract, the Court cannot supply them.â€Â  Laseter v. Pet Dairy Prods. Co., 246 F.2d 747, 750 (4th Cir. 1957).
Section 27-35-60 provides for situations in which the sublease was obtained without the consent of the landlord.Â  In the instant case, Fleshman provided written consent by signing the sublease.Â  Thus, the statute did not create a duty by which Respondents became landlords and were under an obligation to eject Dance America from the premises.Â  In addition to not having a duty to eject, Respondents did not have a statutory right to do so because the applicable statute does not consider them landlords.Â  Fleshman was the landlord and, therefore, the only party with the right to eject Dance America.
Similarly, no contractual responsibility in this regard was created in the sublease.Â  Certainly, Fleshmanâ€™s letter to Trilogy declining to exercise the renewal option did not create a duty to eject.Â  Even assuming for the sake of argument that a contractual responsibility was created in the lease or sublease, Fleshman did not raise this argument at trial, and he cannot raise this issue for the first time on appeal.Â  See, e.g., Brown v. Theos, 338 S.C. 305, 312-13, 526 S.E.2d 232, 237 (Ct. App. 1999).
Any duties Respondents owed to Fleshman ceased upon termination of the lease on August 14, 2002.Â  Thereafter, Dance America would have been either a tenant at will or a trespasser because it was not in possession pursuant to any contract with Respondents or Fleshman.Â  See, e.g., S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 27-33-10(3) (1991) & 27-35-40 (1991) (defining and explaining tenancy at will when a person uses or occupies real estate without an agreement); see also Carson v. Living Word Outreach Ministries, Inc., 315 S.C. 64, 69, 431 S.E.2d 615, 617-18 (Ct. App. 1993) (describing the creation of a tenancy at will after lease termination).Â  Irrespective of Dance Americaâ€™s status, Respondents were not in possession of the premises nor bound by any statutory or contractual relationship with Fleshman or Dance America.Â  Thus, the removal of Dance America was entirely up to Fleshman as owner of the property.Â  
Because Fleshman has not demonstrated that Respondents owed a duty to eject Dance America, he has failed to state a cause of action.Â  Therefore, the trial court did not err in granting Respondentsâ€™ motion to dismiss.
II.Â  Motion to Reconsider, Alter, or Amend the Judgment
Fleshman contends the trial court erred in denying his motion to reconsider because the trial court failed to make findings of fact and conclusions of law pursuant to Rules 41 and 52, SCRCP.Â  We disagree.
According to Rule 41(b), â€œ[i]f the court renders judgment on the merits against the plaintiff, the court shall make findings as provided in Rule 52(a).â€Â  However, Rule 52(a) provides that findings of fact and conclusions of law are unnecessary when a court decides motions under Rule 12.
Rule 41, is not applicable to this case.Â  It applies in situations where the plaintiff has presented all of its evidence.Â  In this case, Respondents moved to dismiss pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6).Â  Because Rule 52, SCRCP does not require the trial court to make findings of fact or conclusions of law in Rule 12 rulings, the trial court did not err in issuing a form order.
AFFIRMED. [2]
HEARN, C.J., KITTREDGE, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] When James Fleshman died on September 3, 2003, Helen L. Fleshman, as the personal representative of the estate of James Fleshman, was substituted as the plaintiff in the action.Â

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
A.S., a high school student in Greenville County, and her Parents, Respondents,
v.
School District of Greenville County, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Charles B. Simmons, Jr., Special Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-360
Submitted April 1, 2005 â€“ Filed May 23, 2005

AFFIRMED IN PART
REVERSED IN PART


  
    
      
C. Wade Cleveland, of Greenville, for Appellant.
Stephen John Henry, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  The School District of Greenville (the District) appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order reversing the expulsion of A.S., a student at Eastside High School, for bringing a knife onto campus.Â  Using the scope of review pursuant to the Administrative Procedures Act, the circuit court found substantial evidence did not support the decision to expel A.S.Â  We affirm in part and reverse in part.[1]
FACTS
After school on November 13, 2002, sixteen-year-old A.S. brought a knife, along with other construction materials, into the school library to cut foam board for nametags for an extracurricular activity called Youth in Government.Â  The schoolâ€™s media specialist working in the library at the time confiscated the knife and took it to Stan Hopkins, a school administrator.Â  Hopkins brought the knife to principal Sheryl Taylor who reported the incident to the District.Â  
By letter dated November 13, 2002, Taylor informed A.S.â€™s parents she was suspended â€œpending a recommendation for expulsionâ€ for â€œpossession of a knife on campus.â€Â  On November 14, 2002, Taylor sent A.S.â€™s parents a letter indicating that because A.S. brought a knife with a four-inch blade onto the schoolâ€™s campus, Taylor recommended A.S. for expulsion in accordance with the Districtâ€™s zero tolerance policy.Â  A.S.â€™s parents wrote a letter to the Districtâ€™s Board of Trustees (the â€œBoardâ€) requesting A.S. be readmitted to school because A.S. only brought a â€œserrated kitchen knifeâ€ to school to use as a tool.Â  
Taylorâ€™s recommendation resulted in a hearing before Dr. Don Dempsey, the District Hearing Officer, on November 21, 2002.Â  Dempsey had before him a file and submissions from A.S.â€™s attorney.Â  This included an affidavit from A.S.â€™s physician that explained how A.S.â€™s attention deficit hyperactivity disorder affected her ability to control her impulses.Â  Additionally, Dempsey heard testimony from A.S. and her mother as well as from Taylor.Â  A.S. admitted bringing a â€œkitchen knifeâ€ to school, and her mother described the knife as having a â€œlong blade.â€Â  In closing arguments, A.S.â€™s attorney argued that although his client brought a knife to school with a â€œblade longer than two inches,â€ A.S. had no intent to use the knife as a weapon.Â  
Based upon this evidence, Dempsey found A.S. violated the Districtâ€™s rules by bringing a knife onto campus and ordered her expelled for the remainder of the 2002-2003 school year.Â  The District confirmed the decision by letter stating A.S. could apply for readmission to Eastside for the 2003-2004 school year and outlined the procedure for appealing Dempseyâ€™s decision to the Board.Â  On appeal, the Board upheld the expulsion, but it shortened the expulsion period from the remainder of the year to the remainder of the semester.Â  As a result, A.S. would miss only three weeks of school and could reapply for admission for the second semester of the 2002-2003 school year in January 2003.Â  
A.S. appealed to the circuit court, and the court reversed.Â  The court found the Districtâ€™s expulsion policy required it to establish A.S. brought a knife over two inches long to school, or alternatively, to establish A.S. brought a knife with a blade less than two inches long to school with the intention of inflicting bodily injury or death.Â  The court found there was no evidence in the record of the knife bladeâ€™s length and that A.S. had no intent to inflict bodily injury or death.Â  Applying the substantial evidence standard of review pursuant to the Administrative Procedures Act (APA), the circuit court reversed the Boardâ€™s decision.Â  The District appealed.Â  Â Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Mootness
As an initial matter, we address whether the issue before us is moot.Â  Generally, an appellate court will not address a moot question or make an adjudication when no actual controversy remains.Â  Byrd v. Irmo High School, 321 S.C. 426, 431-32, 468 S.E.2d 861, 864 (1996) (addressing mootness with regard to a studentâ€™s ten-day suspension).Â  A case becomes moot when judgment, if rendered, will have no practical legal effect upon an existing controversy.Â  This is true when some event occurs making it impossible for the reviewing court to grant effectual relief.Â  Id.Â  
In Byrd, our supreme court was asked to decide whether review of a studentâ€™s ten-day suspension was warranted because the student had served the suspension by the time the matter reached the appellate court.Â  The court noted an exception to the mootness doctrine allows a court to take jurisdiction if the issued raised was capable of repetition but evading review.Â  Byrd, 321 S.C. at 431, 468 S.E.2d at 864.Â  The exception does not require that the same complaining party be subject to the action again, but that the controversy presents a recurring dilemma that the court will address to clarify the law.Â  Id.; Evans v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs., 303 S.C. 108, 110 n.1, 399 S.E.2d 156, 157 n.1 (1990).
Even assuming the issue in the present case is moot because A.S.â€™s expulsion ended as of January 2003 and we can grant no effectual relief, we find the issue is capable of repetition but evading review.Â  As in Byrd, short-term student expulsions, like short-term student suspensions, are â€œcompleted long before an appellate court can review the issues they implicate.â€Â  Byrd, 321 S.C. at 432, 468 S.E.2d at 864.Â  Therefore, the instant case fits within the exception to the mootness doctrine.Â Â  
II. Application of the APA
The District argues the circuit court erred in finding the APA applies to judicial review of decisions by a school board.Â  Under the APA, a reviewing court may reverse or modify the decision, in part, if it is â€œclearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative and substantial evidence on the whole record.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6)(e) (2005); Laws v. Richland County Sch. Dist. No. 1, 270 S.C. 492, 495-96, 243 S.E.2d 192, 193 (1978) (holding the substantial evidence standard of review applies to judicial review of a school boardâ€™s decision regarding whether to renew a teacherâ€™s contract).Â  However, the District concedes in its brief that the â€œsubstantial evidenceâ€ standard of review is the appropriate one.Â  Therefore, any potential error in applying the â€œsubstantial evidenceâ€ standard pursuant to the APA is harmless and the question is moot.Â  See Brown v. Allstate Ins. Co., 344 S.C. 21, 25, 542 S.E.2d 723, 725 (2001) (finding the erroneous admission of certain evidence was harmless where it would not affect the outcome).Â  Accordingly, we decline to address this issue.Â  See Gainey v. Gainey, 279 S.C. 68, 69, 301 S.E.2d 763, 764 (1983) (â€œThis Court will not issue advisory opinions on questions for which no meaningful relief can be granted.â€).Â  
III. Substantial Evidence
The District argues the circuit court erred in determining that substantial evidence did not support the Boardâ€™s decision to expel A.S.Â  Even though the parties agree that the circuit court appropriately examined the expulsion decision under the substantial evidence standard, we find the circuit court erred in reversing the Boardâ€™s decision to expel A.S. for possession of a knife on school property.Â  
The Districtâ€™s disciplinary code defines what is considered misconduct for which disciplinary action is appropriate.Â  Bringing a weapon to school, including a knife with a blade less than two inches long, is defined as misconduct warranting disciplinary action, including suspension or expulsion as a last resort.Â  Policy JD(P) Â§Â§ I.A & I.B.1 (emphasis added). However, the Districtâ€™s policy requires that certain serious misconduct, including possession of any kind of weapon, â€œwill result in the principalâ€™s recommendation for expulsion.â€Â  Policy JD(P) Â§ I.C.1.A.Â  In defining â€œweapon,â€ the Districtâ€™s policy states that it â€œincludes, but is not limited to, guns, blackjacks, brass knuckles, razors, box openers, knives, with a blade over two inches long, or any other device or object that is possessed or used with the intention of inflicting bodily injury or death.â€Â  Id.Â  (emphasis added).Â  
The circuit court reviewed the Districtâ€™s policy and the evidence presented at the hearing before Dr. Dempsey.Â  The circuit court determined that in order to recommend expulsion, the District necessarily had to prove that the knife blade exceeded two inches long or that A.S. possessed something with the intent to inflict bodily injury or death.Â  The court determined that there was no evidence on the record regarding the length of the knife blade in question and that there was no evidence that A.S. intended to harm anyone.Â  Based on what it perceived to be a lack of evidence, the court reversed the Districtâ€™s decision to expel A.S.Â  
Our review of the record indicates substantial evidence existed to support the Districtâ€™s decision.Â  Although the District did not introduce the knife at the hearing, no one disputed the contention that the knife A.S. brought to school had a blade longer than two inches.Â  Additionally, the testimony and letters presented at the hearing show the knife blade was longer than two inches.Â  In her letter to A.S.â€™s parents the day following the incident, Taylor stated that A.S. brought a â€œknife with a four-inch blade onto the campus of Eastside High School.â€Â  A.S.â€™s parents did not dispute Taylorâ€™s contention and admitted in a letter to the School Board that A.S. brought a â€œserrated kitchen knifeâ€ to school.Â  At the hearing, A.S. described the knife as a â€œkitchen knife,â€ and her mother stated that the knife had a â€œlong blade.â€Â  Further, A.S.â€™s counsel admitted in closing arguments that the blade was â€œlonger than two inches.â€Â  
No one disputes that A.S. was a fine student and that she had innocent motives in bringing the kitchen knife to school.Â  Nevertheless, we find there was substantial evidence to support the Boardâ€™s decision to expel A.S., pursuant to the Districtâ€™s mandatory policy, for bringing a knife with a blade longer than two inches to school.Â  Accordingly, the circuit court erred in reversing the Boardâ€™s decision to expel A.S.
CONCLUSION
Although our decision will have no practical legal effect on the controversy at issue, we address this appeal because the situation is capable of repetition yet evading review.Â  As the District concedes, the circuit court appropriately used the substantial evidence standard of review.Â  Based upon the substantial evidence standard of review and our review of the record, we find the circuit court erred in overturning A.S.â€™s expulsion.Â  Therefore, the order of the circuit court is 
AFFIRMED IN PART and REVERSED IN PART.
ANDERSON, BEATTY, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Jerry Marvin Galbreath, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Oconee County
Â Alexander S. Macaulay, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-361
Heard April 5, 2005 â€“ Filed May 23, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, Senior Asst. Attorney General William Edgar Salter, III, Office of the Attorney General, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Druanne Dykes White, of Anderson, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Jerry Marvin Galbreath appeals his convictions for murder and possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent crime.Â  He argues the trial court erred in denying his motion for a directed verdict and in allowing rebuttal testimony of an investigating officer. Â We affirm.
FACTS
On the evening of December 27, 2002, Galbreath and his roommate, Johnny Dillard, partied with the victim, Shawn Bates, and the victimâ€™s girlfriend, Pamela Ayers.Â  Both Ayers and Dillard testified that Galbreath and Bates huffed paint, smoked marijuana, and drank alcohol while the four of them drove to a bar.Â  While Bates was in the bar, Galbreath repeatedly told Ayers that he was going to â€œrape herâ€ and kill Bates.Â Â  
Ayers told Bates that Galbreath was harassing her.Â  When the four returned to the car, Bates and Galbreath began fighting, and Galbreath sustained minor cuts and bruises.Â  Ayers testified the fight began because Bates threatened to take Galbreathâ€™s car, to which Galbreath replied Bates would be a â€œdead manâ€ and â€œdie that nightâ€ if he tried.Â  Dillard, who was driving the vehicle, pulled over and ordered Bates and Ayers out of the vehicle.Â  Once Dillard and Galbreath arrived back at Galbreathâ€™s home, Dillard parked the car in the garage, and the men went inside.Â  Dillard testified that they continued drinking.Â  At one point Galbreath told Dillard, â€œI will get the little fucker for busting my eyes.Â  I will get even with the bastard.â€Â Â  
After being dropped off, Bates and Ayers went to the home of Lynn Davis, who lived near the location where Dillard had left the couple.Â  Bates requested Lynn Davis take him to Galbreathâ€™s home so he could retrieve a baseball cap that he had left in the car.Â  Davis, accompanied by her friend, Kimberly Skinner, and Ayers, drove Bates to Galbreathâ€™s home.Â  Although Ayers, Davis, and Skinner testified that Bates seemed calm on the way to Galbreathâ€™s house, Ayers admitted that he was angry because he did not have his hat.Â Â Â  
After arriving at Galbreathâ€™s residence, Bates tried to open the garage door but could not.Â  He hit the garage door with a brick and smeared leaves onto the door.Â  He also leaned a ladder against the house, but he did not attempt to use the ladder for any purpose.Â  Frustrated, Bates returned to Davisâ€™s vehicle, and Davis backed out of the driveway.Â  As the vehicle was leaving the driveway, Galbreathâ€™s porch light came on, and Bates told Davis to stop the car.Â  Bates exited the vehicle and walked toward the house with â€œhis arms out with his hands spread.â€Â  Ayers, Davis, and Skinner heard a gun shot.Â  Bates then returned to the vehicle where he stated Galbreath had shot him.Â  Ayers saw Galbreath close the glass door.Â  Davis drove away from Galbreathâ€™s residence, and an ambulance was called, but Bates did not survive.
Dillard testified that he awoke around midnight because he heard knocking or banging on the house.Â  He could also hear Bates outside yelling about wanting his belongings from the car.Â  Dillard returned to bed once the knocking stopped, but woke again moments later when he heard Galbreath and Bates cursing at each other.Â  Dillard then heard a gun shot, whereupon he arose from bed and found Galbreath holding a .22 rifle out the open doorway.Â  Dillard claimed Galbreath told him that he shot Bates, but â€œwished [Bates] would have tried to break in.â€ Â Â Â Â 
Neither Galbreath nor Dillard called 911.Â  According to Dillard, Galbreath listened to his police scanner before going to bed.Â Â  
The police arrested Galbreath the following morning, on December 28, 2002.Â  In May of 2003, a jury found Galbreath guilty of murder and possession of a firearm during a violent crime.Â  The trial court sentenced him to thirty years imprisonment for murder and five years imprisonment for possession of a firearm during a violent crime.Â  This appeal followed.Â Â Â  
LAW/ ANALYSIS
Galbreath claims the trial court erred in denying his motion for a directed verdict because he was acting in self-defense and in defense of habitation.Â  We disagree.
When ruling on a motion for a directed verdict in a criminal case, the trial court is concerned with the existence or non-existence of evidence, not its weight.Â  State v. Morgan, 282 S.C. 409, 411, 319 S.E.2d 335, 336 (1984).Â  In reviewing the denial of a motion for a directed verdict, the evidence is viewed in the light most favorable to the State.Â  State v. Fennell, 340 S.C. 266, 270, 531 S.E.2d 512, 514 (2000).Â  If there is any direct evidence or substantial circumstantial evidence reasonably tending to prove the guilt of the accused, we must find the case was properly submitted to the jury.Â  State v. Pinckney, 339 S.C. 346, 349, 529 S.E.2d 526, 527 (2000).Â  â€œA defendant is entitled to a directed verdict when the State fails to produce evidence of the offense charged.â€ Â State v. McHoney, 344 S.C. 85, 97, 544 S.E.2d 30, 36 (2001).Â  Thus, in the present case, unless it can be said as a matter of law that self-defense or defense of habitation was established, it was not error to submit the case to the jury.
In order to establish that a crime was committed in self-defense, a defendant must show: 


  (1) he was without fault in bringing on the difficulty;
(2) he actually believed he was in imminent danger of losing his life or of sustaining serious bodily injury;
(3) a reasonably prudent person of ordinary firmness and courage would have entertained the same belief;
(4) he had no other probable means of avoiding the danger.

State v. Long, 325 S.C. 59, 62, 480 S.E.2d 62, 63 (1997).Â  Defense of habitation is analogous to self-defense, except that â€œa person attacked on his own premises, without fault, has the right to claim immunity from the law of retreat.â€Â  Id.Â  However, as with self-defense, the defendantâ€™s subjective belief of imminent danger must be reasonable.Â  State v. Lee, 293 S.C. 536, 537, 362 S.E.2d 24, 25 (1987).Â  
Here, the trial court properly submitted the case to the jury because there was evidence that Galbreath did not believe he was in imminent danger of losing life or sustaining serious bodily injury.Â  Dillard, Ayers, and Davis testified that Bates was unarmed.Â  Furthermore, Ayers and Davis stated that Bates approached Galbreathâ€™s house with â€œhis arms out with his hands spread,â€ making the fact that Bates did not have a weapon evident.Â  Dillard testified that Galbreath declared, after the shooting, that he â€œwished [Bates] would have tried to break in,â€ which provides some evidence that Galbreath did not believe Bates was trying to break into his home. Â Therefore, we find the State presented enough evidence to survive a directed verdict motion.Â  Â Â 
Galbreath also claims the trial court erred in allowing Officer Chastainâ€™s testimony as rebuttal evidence to the statement Galbreath made to police because the State elicited the statement during cross-examination.Â  We disagree.
When the defendant has completed his case, the prosecuting party may offer evidence in reply.Â 
McGaha v. Mosley, 283 S.C. 268, 276, 322 S.E.2d 461, 466 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  â€œThe admission of reply testimony is within the sound discretion of the trial judge, and there is no abuse of discretion if the testimony is arguably contradictory of and in reply to earlier testimony.â€Â  State v. Todd, 290 S.C. 212, 214, 349 S.E.2d 339, 340 (1986).Â  Reply testimony can also be used to clarify matters that were confused during the defendantâ€™s case, to rebut an affirmative defense raised during the defendantâ€™s case, and most importantly in this case, to complete the impeachment of a defense witness.Â  See, e.g., State v. Van Williams, 212 S.C. 110, 113, 46 S.E.2d 665, 666-67 (1948); Ford v. A.A.A. Highway Express, 204 S.C. 433, 441-42, 29 S.E.2d 760, 763-64 (1944) (holding plaintiff was on notice that rebuttal evidence may be offered when cross-examination of plaintiffâ€™s witness elicited contradictory evidence).Â  
During his testimony, Galbreath stated he heard a â€œbig crashâ€ when Bates threw objects against the garage door.Â  He also heard Bates screaming â€œlike an animal.â€Â  He testified he was afraid for his life because he heard Bates say, â€œIâ€™ll kill you old man.â€Â  Most importantly, Galbreath testified that Bates had a knife when Dillard kicked him and Ayers out of the vehicle.Â  He also testified that he was â€œsorry about the boy.â€ 
However, during cross-examination, the State presented the statement Galbreath made to Officer Chastain, which detailed many of the events of December 27-28, 2000, including Batesâ€™s threats and the fight in the car. Â In this statement, Galbreath failed to mention that he felt his life was in danger or that Bates was screaming and throwing objects against the garage door.Â  Galbreath also neglected to mention to Officer Chastain, whom he knew well, that Bates had been armed with a knife earlier in the evening.Â  Furthermore, in contrast to what Galbreath testified to at trial, in his statement to Officer Chastain, Galbreath said that he felt sorry for Batesâ€™s mother â€œfor losing a kid, but he didnâ€™t feel bad for [Bates].â€Â Â  
After the defense rested its case, the State called Officer Chastain to rebut Galbreathâ€™s testimony.Â Â  Officer Chastainâ€™s testimony impeached Galbreathâ€™s trial testimony because Galbreath did not say the same things on the stand that he had said to Officer Chastain regarding the incident.Â  Therefore, the trial court did not abuse its discretion in allowing the rebuttal testimony.Â  See Todd, 290 S.C. at 214, 349 S.E.2d at 340 (finding reply testimony was admissible where witnessâ€™s testimony contradicted part of defendantâ€™s testimony).Â  
CONCLUSION 
For the reasons stated herein, Galbreathâ€™s convictions are
 AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and KITTREDGE and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

title: Atherton v. Tenet Healthcare Corporation
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Stephen Atherton, On behalf of himself and all others similarly situated,
Appellant,
v.
Tenet Healthcare Corporation and AMISUB of South Carolina, Inc.,
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
Â Paul E. Short, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2005-UP-362
Heard May 11, 2005 â€“ Filed May 25, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Chad McGowan and Kevin Sitnik, both of Rock Hill, and Gordon Ball, of Knoxville, for Appellant.
Daniel J. Westbrook and Alice V. Harris, both of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  This is a class action[1] arising out of the alleged overcharging by Tenet Healthcare Corporation and AMISUB of South Carolina, Inc. (collectively Respondents), for medical services rendered at Piedmont Medical Center.Â  The court granted summary judgment to Respondents on Athertonâ€™s claims of breach of contract, unjust enrichment, implied contract for value, and his request for an injunction.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
In 1980, York County, the Trustees of York General Hospital, American Medical International, Inc., and AMISUB of South Carolina, Inc.
entered into a contract for American Medical[2] and AMISUB to lease York General Hospital and to construct a replacement hospital.[3]Â  In section 16.15 of the 1980 contract, it specifies â€œ[t]here are no third party beneficiaries of this Agreement.â€Â  Both parties agree Atherton was not a party to this contract.Â  
The contract was subsequently modified on seven different occasions, through seven addenda to the 1980 contract.Â  In August 1995, Respondents and York County executed the Sixth Addendum.Â  The Sixth Addendum provided in part that â€œin order to ensure the continuing provision of high quality, cost effective healthcare to the citizens of York County without cost to York County, [Respondents] have proposed to undertake various obligations expanding upon, or in addition to, those contained in [the 1980 Agreement].â€Â  This addendum also contained the following provisions relevant to this appeal:
Section 3.1(e) Pricing
AMI acknowledges that, in addition to the securing of the highest quality health care for the citizens of York County, a major objective of York County in entering into this Agreement is that such care be provided on a cost-effective basis at prices favorably comparable to those paid for similar services provided by comparable acute-care hospitals in the same general geographical area. . . . Both parties understand that cost-effective, competitive pricing for services provided at the Hospital is essential to the provision of quality health care services to the citizens of York County, to the continuing economic well being of the Hospital and to the ability of AMI to meet its obligations hereunder.Â  AMI agrees to exert every effort to so conduct its operations and finances to maintain prices for services at the Hospital at reasonable, competitive levels vis a vis other hospitals in the â€œpeer groupâ€ . . . . In the event such pricing information shall show that the average charge per case by the Hospital for â€œAll Product Linesâ€ is the highest in the peer group, AMI shall, within twelve (12) months following the delivery of such information to York County, present to York County, and implement a plan reasonably expected to fix or reduce its costs and/or charges for services such that the average charge per case for All Product Lines at the Hospital will be less than the highest in such peer group.Â  If such average charge remains the highest in the peer group at the end of the second Medpar reporting period following the reporting period which first showed the Hospitalâ€™s having the highest average charge, AMI shall not increase any charges for services at the Hospital until such time as there have been delivered to York County reports . . . which show the Hospitalâ€™s average charge per case for All Product Lines being less than the highest of the peer group.
Section 4.2 Remedies on Default

(a) Whenever any event of default . . . shall have happened and be subsisting, York County make (sic) take whatever action at law or in equity may appear necessary or desirable to enforce performance and observance of any obligation, agreement or covenant of [Respondents] under this Agreement.
(b) Whenever any event of default described [in specific sections of the Addendum] shall have happened and be subsisting, York County shall, in addition (sic) any remedy available to is (sic) pursuant to subsection (a), above, have the right . . . to purchase the Hospital.

(emphasis added).Â  Importantly, section 5 of the Sixth Addendum â€œratified and confirmedâ€ those sections of the 1980 contract not expressly modified by the addendum.Â  
Atherton and the other class members received medical services at Piedmont Medical Center since the 1995 date of the Sixth Addendum.Â  For each service rendered by the Hospital, Atherton entered into agreements entitled â€œConsent for Treatment and Conditions of Admission.â€Â  These agreements included a provision in which Atherton â€œindividually obligates [himself] to pay the account of the hospital in accordance with the regular rates and terms of the hospital and physicians.â€Â  
In his complaint, Atherton asserts: â€œFor the last several years, the hospital charges for Tenet and Amisub have been the highest in the group of 10 peer hospitals in the region . . . .â€Â  Atherton alleges that York County entered into the agreement â€œto directly benefit the citizens and residents of York Countyâ€ and that they were â€œthe intended beneficiaries of the agreement between York County and [Respondents].â€Â  He sets forth four causes of action:Â  (1) breach of third-party beneficiary contract; (2) unjust enrichment; (3) breach of implied contract for value of goods and services received; and (4) injunctive relief.Â  Respondents answered setting forth numerous defenses, including the defense that neither Atherton nor the purported class were third-party beneficiaries to the agreement and thus lacked standing to enforce the contract.Â  Additionally, Respondents filed a motion for summary judgment.Â  
Following a hearing on the matter, the trial court granted Respondentsâ€™ motion for summary judgment.Â  The court found that there were no third-party beneficiaries under the contract, at best the citizens of York County were incidental beneficiaries, and Atherton did not have a right to enforce the provisions of the contract.Â  The court held Athertonâ€™s claim of unjust enrichment was barred because his assertion was based on an alleged breach of a contract, he asserted no legal duty or obligation upon which to base such a claim, and he was attempting to establish an additional remedy not provided for under the contract.Â  
The court went on to find neither South Carolina, nor any other jurisdiction, has recognized a cause of action for the breach of an implied contract for value of goods and services received, and even if it did exist, Athertonâ€™s claim fails because his payments were covered by express contracts with the Hospital.Â  The court also concluded he was not entitled to injunctive relief.Â  Finally, the court held all four of Athertonâ€™s claims would require the court to engage in legislative â€œrate-makingâ€ in order to determine damages, in violation of the separation of powers doctrine, and Respondents were entitled to summary judgment on this basis as well on all four causes of action.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, this court applies the same standard which governs the trial court:Â  summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP; Baughman v. Am. Tel. & Tel. Co., 306 S.C. 101, 114-15, 410 S.E.2d 537, 545 (1991).Â  In determining whether any triable issues of fact exist, the evidence and all inferences which can be reasonably drawn from the evidence must be viewed in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  Strother v. Lexington County Recreation Commâ€™n, 332 S.C. 54, 61, 504 S.E.2d 117, 121 (1998).Â  On appeal from an order granting summary judgment, the appellate court will review all ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising in and from the evidence in a light most favorable to the non-moving party below.Â  Osborne v. Adams, 346 S.C. 4, 7, 550 S.E.2d 319, 321 (2001).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Atherton contends the trial court erred in granting summary judgment in favor of Respondents on his four claims.Â  We disagree.
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Breach of Third-Party Beneficiary Contract
Atherton contends the trial court erred in finding the agreement between Respondents and York County clearly and unambiguously precluded third-party beneficiaries.Â  He argues the Sixth Addendum modified the 1980 contract such that it now allows for enforcement of its provisions by citizens of the county.Â  He maintains, in the alternative, the agreement is at least ambiguous as to whether the citizens of York County are third party beneficiaries such that summary judgment was improper.Â  We disagree.
â€œSouth Carolina contract law carries a presumption that an individual who is not a party to a contract lacks privity to enforce it.â€Â  Trancik v. USAA Ins. Co., 354 S.C. 549, 553, 581 S.E.2d 858, 861 (Ct. App. 2003) (citing Touchberry v. City of Florence, 295 S.C. 47, 48-49, 367 S.E.2d 149, 150 (1988)).Â  â€œ[I]t is to be observed that the presumption is that parties contract for their own benefit, and not for that of others not parties to the contract.â€Â  Ancrum v. Camden Water, Light & Ice Co., 82 S.C. 284, 295, 64 S.E. 151, 155 (1909).Â  â€œGenerally, one not in privity of contract with another cannot maintain an action against him in breach of contract, and any damage resulting from the breach of a contract between the defendant and a third party is not, as such, recoverable by the plaintiff.â€Â  Bob Hammond Constr. Co. v. Banks Constr. Co., 312 S.C. 422, 424, 440 S.E.2d 890, 891 (Ct. App. 1994).Â  The presumption is sustained that a contract made by a public entity is made on behalf of the public at large, and not for the benefit of the individual citizens.Â  Ancrum, 82 S.C. at 295, 64 S.E. at 155.Â  However, the presumption may be overcome if the intent of the parties to the contract was to provide the third-party a direct benefit, rather than an incidental or consequential one.Â  Id. at 424, 440 S.E.2d at 891; Cothran v. Rock Hill, 211 S.C. 17, 20, 43 S.E.2d 615, 616-17 (1947).Â  In addition, a municipality or other public entity may enter into a contract which allows for enforcement by an individual citizen if the parties so intended such enforcement and provided for the relief sought by the third-party.Â  Ancrum, 82 S.C. at 295, 64 S.E. at 155; Peeples v. South Carolina Power Co., 166 S.C. 150, 156-58, 164 S.E. 605, 607-08 (1932).
The cardinal rule of contract interpretation is to ascertain and give legal effect to the intentions of the parties, as determined by the contract language.Â  Schulmeyer v. State Farm Fire & Cas. Co., 353 S.C. 491, 495, 579 S.E.2d 132, 134 (2003).Â  Courts are without authority to alter a contract by construction or to make new contracts for the parties, and words cannot be read into a contract which impart an intent wholly unexpressed when the contract was executed.Â  Gilstrap v. Culpepper, 283 S.C. 83, 86, 320 S.E.2d 445, 447 (1984).Â  â€œWhen a contract is unambiguous a court must construe its provisions according to the terms the parties used; understood in their plain, ordinary, and popular sense.â€Â  Schulmeyer, 353 S.C. at 134, 579 S.E.2d at 495.
In the instant case, there is no indication the parties intended to provide individual citizens with the right to enforce the contract or to hold Respondents liable to individual citizens for a breach of the contract.Â  The 1980 contract specifically and explicitly excludes third-party beneficiaries from the contract.Â  In section 16.15 of the contract, it specifies â€œ[t]here are no third party beneficiaries of this agreement.â€Â  Although the 1995 Sixth Addendum has provisions for pricing such as section 3.1(e) that may provide a consequential benefit to individual citizens of York County, the addendum does nothing to change the partiesâ€™ express intention to prohibit third-party beneficiaries.[4]Â  The addendum fully adopts and ratifies the unmodified portions of the 1980 contract, which includes section 16.15 limiting third-party beneficiaries.Â  
Further, unlike Peeples, which is relied on by Atherton, default provision section 4.2 of the Sixth Addendum provides for specific remedies reserved to York County alone.Â  The public contract in Peeples â€œ[did] not expressly provide the consequences of a breach, so as to exclude other consequences.â€Â  Peeples, 166 S.C. at 158, 164 S.E. at 607.Â  As noted in Ancrum, whenever parties to a contract stipulate in the contract the consequences of a breach of the agreement, if the stipulation is reasonable, it is controlling and excludes other consequences.Â  Ancrum, 82 S.C. at 297, 64 S.E. at 156.Â  Neither section 4.2, nor any other proviso in the contract or addendum, provide for individual rights of enforcement or remedies in the event of a breach.Â  Rather, the contract in question fixed and limited the consequences of any breach by Respondents, and as noted by the trial court, â€œthe court cannot add to the contract by imposing other and additional consequences.â€Â  Id.Â  As the contract specifies a remedy, and reserves that remedy exclusively to York County, we find this case clearly distinguishable from Peeples.Â  Accordingly, we find the agreement between the parties is unambiguous and the parties did not intend to allow Respondents to be liable to individual citizens of York County.Â  Therefore, the trial court properly granted summary judgment to Respondents on Athertonâ€™s claim for breach of contract. 
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Unjust Enrichment
Atherton asserts the trial court erred in granting summary judgment on its claim for unjust enrichment.Â  He maintains the claim is not required to be based upon a legal duty owed by Respondents and is not rooted in his claim for breach of contract.Â  We find the court properly granted summary judgment on Athertonâ€™s claim for unjust enrichment.
 Quantum meruit, quasi-contract, and implied by law contract are all equivalent terms for invoking an equitable remedy.Â  Myrtle Beach Hospital, Inc. v. City of Myrtle Beach, 341 S.C. 1, 8, 532 S.E.2d 868, 872 (2000).Â  Our Supreme Court has noted:Â  â€œwe used the terms quantum meruit, quasi-contract, and contract implied by law as equivalent terms, to distinguish those situations where equity would aid recovery from those where law provided the remedy, that is, express contracts or contracts implied in fact.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œIn a law action, the measure of damages is determined by the partiesâ€™ agreement, while in equity, â€˜the measure of the recovery is the extent of the duty or obligation imposed by law, and is expressed by the amount which the court considers the defendant has been unjustly enriched at the expense of the plaintiff.â€™â€Â  Id. (quoting United States Rubber Products, Inc. v. Town of Batesburg, 183 S.C. 49, 190 S.E. 120 (1937)).
To prevail on a quantum meruit/quasi contract/implied by law claim, the plaintiff must establish the following elements:Â  (1) a benefit conferred by the plaintiff upon the defendant; (2) realization of that benefit by the defendant; and (3) retention of the benefit by the defendant under circumstances that make it inequitable for him to retain it without paying its value.Â  Id. at 8-9, 532 S.E.2d at 872.Â  It should be noted, however, â€œ[i]f the tasks the plaintiff is seeking compensation for under a quantum meruit theory are encompassed within the terms of an express contract which has not been abandoned or rescinded, the plaintiff may not recover under quantum meruit.â€Â  Swanson v. Stratos, 350 S.C. 116, 122, 564 S.E.2d 117, 120 (Ct. App. 2002) (citing with approval 66 Am. Jur. 2d Restitution and Implied Contracts Â§ 81 (2001)) (â€œ[I]t is a defense to an action in quantum meruit that there is an express contract covering the issue of compensation for services or materials furnished.â€).
Atherton contends the trial court erred in ruling he could not maintain a claim for unjust enrichment based on an alleged breach of contract.Â  He asserts he is not prohibited from maintaining an unjust enrichment claim by the agreement between York County and Respondents because he is not a party to that contract.Â  While the order of the trial court appears to be referring to the agreement between York County and Respondents when it sets forth the law that one cannot recover for unjust enrichment where an express contract exists, this is due to the fact Atherton couched his complaint as relying on this agreement to show Respondents were unjustly enriched.Â  Specifically, in asserting his unjust enrichment claim, Athertonâ€™s allegations in entirety are as follows:

53.Â  Defendant wrongfully charged the Plaintiff and every other person similarly situated to the Plaintiff when it insisted upon a price for medical services which was in excess of the highest amount of any hospital in the 10 member peer group as agreed to by contract with York County.Â  The defendants have paid the money for charges which were in abrogation of the agreement with York County and, thus, Tenet and Amisub have been unjustly enriched.
54.Â  Plaintiff is individually entitled to judgment in their (sic) favor against the Defendants in the amount of all charges by Piedmont Medical Center that were in excess of the highest amount of any hospital in the 10 member peer group, plus reasonable interest, and each person in a class of persons similarly situated is entitled to judgment in their (sic) favor against the Defendants in the amount of all charges by Piedmont Medical Center that were in excess of the highest amount of any hospital in the 10 member peer group.

Thus, Atherton has based his claim for unjust enrichment on the agreement between York County and Respondents.Â  As previously noted, this express contract precludes any recovery by Atherton as a third-party beneficiary under the contract.Â  Clearly, as noted by the trial court, Atherton is merely attempting to reframe his breach of contract action as an action for unjust enrichment.Â  
At any rate, we find in the instant case there are other express contracts, which cover the issue of the amount paid by Atherton to the Hospital in exchange for its medical services, that preclude Athertonâ€™s claim for unjust enrichment.[5]Â  Atherton signed consent agreements in which he agreed to â€œpay the account of the hospital in accordance with the regular rates and terms of the hospital and physicians.â€Â  He cannot now claim recovery under an implied contract when he and the Hospital each performed under an express contract which was neither abandoned nor rescinded.Â  
Finally, even if we went beyond the issue of express contracts covering the issue of compensation for services furnished, Athertonâ€™s claim must fail.Â  In Pitts v. Jackson Natâ€™l Life Ins. Co., 352 S.C. 319, 574 S.E.2d 502 (Ct. App. 2002), Pitts sued Jackson National asserting, in part, a claim for unjust enrichment based on the insurance companyâ€™s failure to issue a preferred policy instead of a standard policy on his daughter, because his daughter qualified for the preferred policy, which charged lower premiums than the standard policies of equal face value.Â  This court noted the elements that a plaintiff must establish in order to recover for unjust enrichment; i.e. that there be (1) a benefit conferred by the plaintiff upon the defendant; (2) realization of that benefit by the defendant; and (3) retention of the benefit by the defendant under circumstances that make it inequitable for him to retain it without paying its value.Â  Id.Â  at 339, 574 S.E.2d at 512.Â  We found that there was no benefit conferred upon the insurance company that would be unjust for the company to retain.Â  Id.Â  As in Pitts, there simply is no benefit conferred upon Respondents that would be unjust for Respondents to retain.Â  Atherton entered into commercial transactions with Respondents whereby he agreed to pay the hospitalâ€™s and physiciansâ€™ â€œregular ratesâ€ in exchange for services rendered to him.Â  There is no allegation the Hospital was unjustly enriched by taking more than its â€œregular rates,â€ only that it took more than was allowed in the contract between Respondents and York County.Â  If Atherton were allowed to recover on this basis, it would expose Respondents to individual liability on a contract that we have found expressly prohibits individual recovery.Â  Accordingly, we find the trial court properly granted Respondentsâ€™ motion for summary judgment on Athertonâ€™s claim of unjust enrichment. 
III.Â Â Â  Implied Contract for Value of Goods and Services Received
Atherton maintains the trial court erred in finding no cause of action for breach of an implied contract for value of goods and services received may be sustained.Â  We disagree.
Atherton maintains this cause of action is merely a reverse quantum meruit cause of action in which someone who pays too much for a service is entitled to a refund of the amount overpaid.Â  However, as stated above, a plaintiff may not recover under a quantum meruit cause of action where there is an express contract covering the issue of compensation.Â  Swanson v. Stratos, 350 S.C. at 122, 564 S.E.2d at 120.Â  Atherton entered into express contracts with the Hospital to pay at the â€œregular ratesâ€ for the services rendered.Â  When he paid the rate charged, he performed under the contract.Â  
Additionally, Atherton admits this specific cause of action has not been a â€œrecognized cause of action.â€Â  We have found no jurisdiction adopting liability for breach of the implied contract for value of goods and services received and Atherton fails to cite any case which analyzes and/or adopts such a cause of action in South Carolina or any other state.Â  In spite of this lack of precedent, Atherton maintains the court should â€œfashion an equitable remedy.â€Â  However, we find Atherton properly contracted for the services and paid for the services based upon the consent agreements with the Hospital.Â  There is no need to create a new cause of action in equity when the contracts between Atherton and the Hospital expressly cover the issue of payment.
Atherton asks this court, however, to declare the consent agreements void for indefiniteness because the consent agreements fail to properly set forth the price terms.Â  Atherton relies on Doe v. HCA Health Servs. of Tenn., Inc., 46 S.W.3d 191 (Tenn. 2001) for the proposition that where the price is not set but only states the patient assumed liability for charges not paid by insurance, the contract is unenforceable for indefiniteness.Â  However, in Doe, the patient refused to pay the amount billed when it was presented, and instead filed suit seeking to determine a reasonable rate.Â  Id. at 194-95.Â  In the instant case, the record indicates Atherton paid the amount billed by the Hospital.Â  Therefore, there was a meeting of the minds regarding the price and nothing in the record indicates otherwise.Â  
Finally, we have determined Atherton cannot meet the elements necessary in order to recover for unjust enrichment.Â  Because Atherton maintains this cause of action is simply a reverse quantum meruit cause of action, this cause of action fails on that basis as well.Â  Accordingly, we find the trial court properly granted summary judgment on Athertonâ€™s claim of breach of the implied contract for value of goods or services received.
IV.Â Â Â  Injunction
Atherton asserts the trial court erred in ruling he was not entitled to injunctive relief.Â  We disagree.
â€œThe remedy of injunction is a drastic one and should be cautiously applied only when legal rights are unlawfully invaded or legal duties are willfully or wantonly neglected.â€Â  LeFurgy v. Long Cove Club Owners Assâ€™n, Inc., 313 S.C. 555, 558, 443 S.E.2d 577, 578 (Ct. App. 1994).Â  In his complaint, Atherton asserts he is entitled to an injunction enjoining Respondents from seeking fees in excess of that allowed by provisions of the Sixth Addendum to the contract between York County and Respondents.Â  The trial court correctly determined Atherton is attempting to enforce, by way of an injunction, a contract that he has no legal right to enforce.Â  As discussed above, the contract between York County and Respondents allows enforcement by York County and provides the relief allowed.Â  Based upon our holdings above, we find no reason in equity to impose an injunction on Respondents.Â  Accordingly, we find the trial court properly granted summary judgment to Respondents on Athertonâ€™s request for injunctive relief.
CONCLUSION
We find the trial court properly determined Atherton was not a direct third-party beneficiary under the contract between York County and Respondents and therefore has no right of enforcement.Â  We also find Atherton was not entitled to recover under a theory of unjust enrichment or the unprecedented theory of a breach of an implied contract for value of goods or services received.Â  Finally, we hold Atherton was not entitled to injunctive relief in seeking to require Respondents to abide by the terms of the contract or addendum.Â  Accordingly, we find the order of the trial court granting summary judgment to Respondents on all of Athertonâ€™s claims is
AFFIRMED.[6]
GOOLSBY, HUFF, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

[1]For purposes of this appeal, the class allegations are irrelevant.Â  
[2]National Medical Enterprises subsequently acquired American Medical and thereafter changed its name to Tenet Healthcare Corporation.Â  
[3]The replacement hospital is Piedmont Medical Center, which Respondents still operate as of the time of this action.Â  
[4]While the Sixth Addendum provides it was entered in part to ensure the continuing provision of high quality, cost effective healthcare to the citizens of York County, this provision merely expresses the intention to benefit the public at large.Â  We note the 1980 contract also was generally entered into in order to provide certain benefits to the citizens of York County as a whole.Â  Indeed, one provision of the 1980 contract expressly requires Respondents to provide an ambulance service at no charge to the county â€œto meet the needs of all citizens of York County. . . .â€Â  However, the Agreement specifically excludes third-party beneficiaries. 
[5] This court may affirm pursuant to any ground appearing in the record on appeal.Â  See Rule 220(c), SCACR ( â€œThe appellate court may affirm any ruling, order, or judgment upon any ground(s) appearing in the Record on Appeal.â€).
[6]Based on our determination the trial court properly granted summary judgment on each of the individual causes of action, we need not address Athertonâ€™s assertion the trial court committed error in determining Respondents were entitled to summary judgment collectively as to all four causes of action because Athertonâ€™s claims would require the court to engage in legislative â€œrate-makingâ€ in order to determine damages, in violation of the separation of powers doctrine.Â

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Carl C. Hendricks, Jr., Appellant,
v.
Michael R. Ragsdale, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Thomas Kemmerlin, Jr., Master in Equity
Curtis L. Coltrane, Special Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-363
Submitted May 1, 2005 â€“ Filed May 25, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Barry L. Johnson, of Okatie, for Appellant.Â  
Michael R. Ragsdale, of Beaufort, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Carl C. Hendricks, Jr. appeals an order finding two payments he made to Michael Ragsdale were not loans.Â  In addition, Hendricks appeals an order denying him relief from judgment pursuant to Rule 60(b)(3), SCRCP.Â  We affirm.[1]Â  
FACTS
Hendricks filed two actions to collect money based on alleged loans of $60,000 and $25,000 made to Ragsdale.Â  By consent, the actions were consolidated and the master conducted a trial on the merits.Â  By order dated January 16, 2001, the master concluded the payments to Ragsdale were not loans.Â  
The master found that in January of 1990, Hendricks, Ralph Tupper, and Scott Williams borrowed approximately $60,000 from the Savings Bank of Beaufort County.Â  Approximately $30,000 was used to pay a delinquent debt owed by Ragsdale.Â  The remaining $30,000 was paid to Hendricks and Tupper, who endorsed a check in favor of Ragsdale.Â  Hendricks subsequently borrowed an additional $25,000 from South Carolina Federal.Â  The proceeds from this loan were likewise distributed for the benefit of Ragsdale. 
According to the master, there was strongly divergent testimony between the parties as to the disbursements.Â  The master found Ragsdale was more credible.Â  The master concluded, therefore, that the payments were paid â€œto meet a business purpose, and in order to obtain further credit to finance [Hendricksâ€™] interest in forming a new automobile dealershipâ€ or â€œwere business related expenses, or . . . otherwise authorized as compensation of Mr. Ragsdale.â€Â  Accordingly, the master found the payments did not constitute loans.Â  
Hendricks appealed the masterâ€™s order.Â  While the appeal was pending, Hendricks moved this court to hold the appeal in abeyance to enable Hendricks to file a Rule 60(b)(3) motion for relief from judgment.Â  This court held the appeal in abeyance and Hendricks filed his motion, arguing Ragsdale offered perjurious testimony at the trial.Â  Finding the alleged perjured testimony would constitute intrinsic fraud, the circuit court denied the motion.Â  Hendricks appeals both the order finding the payments were not loans and the order denying his Rule 60(b)(3) motion. 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Existence of Indebtedness
Hendricks argues the evidence in the record does not reasonably support the masterâ€™s finding that the payments to Ragsdale were not loans.Â  We disagree. 
â€œAn action to recover on a promissory note is . . . an action at law.â€Â 
Chambers v. Pingree, 351 S.C. 442, 449, 570 S.E.2d 528, 532 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  â€œIn an action at law, on appeal of a case tried without a jury, the findings of fact of the judge will not be disturbed upon appeal unless found to be without evidence which reasonably supports the judgeâ€™s findings.â€Â 
Townes Assocs. v. City of Greenville,
266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976).Â  Based on the record provided and the detailed findings of fact in the masterâ€™s order, we conclude evidence existed to support the masterâ€™s conclusion that the payments made to Ragsdale were not loans.Â  
The master found, and Hendricks does not refute, the alleged loans were not reduced to writing and no written evidence exists to indicate Ragsdale agreed to repay Hendricks.Â  Ragsdale testified that he left a job paying him $60,000 per year to assist Hendricks in finding an automobile dealership.Â  Ragsdale further testified the payments from Hendricks were compensation for his efforts.Â  We find evidence in the record to support the masterâ€™s findings that the amounts paid by Hendricks were not loans.Â  
II.Â  Rule 60(b)
Hendricks also argues the trial court erred in denying him relief from judgment under Rule 60(b)(3), SCRCP.Â  We disagree.Â  Hendricks alleges Ragsdale offered perjured testimony at trial, and therefore, Hendricks is entitled to relief from the judgment.Â  The trial court denied Hendricksâ€™ motion based on Raby Construction v. Orr, 358 S.C. 10, 594 S.E.2d 478 (2004), and Chewning v. Ford Motor Co., 354 S.C. 72, 579 S.E.2d 605 (2003).Â  

Rule 60(b) provides:Â  
  
(b) Mistakes; Inadvertence; Excusable Neglect; Newly Discovered Evidence; Fraud, etc.Â  On motion and upon such terms as are just, the court may relieve a party or his legal representative from a final judgment, order, or proceeding for the following reasons:

  . . . .

  (3) fraud, misrepresentation, or other misconduct of an adverse party;
  

Rule 60(b), SCRCP.
In Chewning v. Ford Motor Co., the South Carolina Supreme
Court announced: "In order to secure equitable relief on the basis of
fraud, the fraud must be extrinsic." 354 S.C. 72, 80, 579 S.E.2d 605, 610
(2003). Further, the court explained the distinction between extrinsic and
intrinsic fraud: 

  Extrinsic fraud is fraud that induces a person not to
  present a case or deprives a person of the opportunity to be heard. Relief is
  granted for extrinsic fraud on the theory that because the fraud prevented a
  party from fully exhibiting and trying his case, there has never been a real
  contest before the court on the subject matter of the action.
Intrinsic fraud, on the other hand, is fraud which was presented and considered in the trial.Â  It is fraud which misleads a court in determining issues and induces the court to find for the party perpetrating the fraud.

Id. at 81, 579 S.E.2d at 610 (internal quotations and citations omitted).Â  The court specifically found that perjury by a party or a witness is intrinsic fraud.Â  Id.  
In Raby Construction v. Orr, the appellant argued that the intrinsic/extrinsic rule from Raby applied only if the Rule 60(b) attack on judgment was more than one year old.Â  358 S.C. 10, 17, 594 S.E.2d 478, 481 (2004).Â  The South Carolina Supreme Court rejected this argument:Â  â€œSouth Carolina maintains the distinction between extrinsic and intrinsic fraud, even when the allegations are raised through a Rule 60(b)(3) motion filed within one year of the entry of judgment.â€Â  Raby, 358 S.C. at 20, 594 S.E.2d at 483.Â  
Hendricks filed a petition with this court to argue against precedent.Â  Article V section 9 of the South Carolina Constitution, governing the jurisdiction of the court of appeals, provides:Â  â€œThe Court of Appeals shall have such jurisdiction as the General Assembly shall prescribe by general law.Â  The decisions of the Supreme Court shall bind the Court of Appeals as precedents.â€Â  S.C. Const. Art. V, Â§ 9 (1985).Â  Thus, we are bound by the precedent established in Raby and Chewning.Â  Under these cases, we find the trial court correctly found Hendricks was not entitled to relief from judgment pursuant to Rule 60(b)(3).Â  
CONCLUSION
We find the record supports the masterâ€™s findings that payments made to Ragsdale by Hendricks were not loans.Â  In addition, we find the trial court did not err in denying Hendricksâ€™ request for relief from judgment pursuant to Rule 60(b)(3), SCRCP.Â  Accordingly, the orders on appeal are
 AFFIRMED. 
ANDERSON, STILWELL, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
